   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 9 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11913**]
   transferred from BMT floor with clinical and laboratory findings
   consistent with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease.
   1) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt now s/p successful intubation after
   presenting w/ rapid shallow breathing, increased O2 requirements, low
   lung volumes on CXR [**3-4**] ascites, and serial ABGs demonstrating
   respiratory fatigue. Respiratory alkalosis is compensatory for
   metabolic acidosis [**3-4**] liver failure. Etiology of hypoxia is less
   clear. Most likely explanation is V/Q mismatch [**3-4**] atelectasis, with
   possible component of pulmonary edema [**3-4**] volume overload. No evidence
   for PNA on CXR. PE also a remote possibility, given tachycardia,
   tachypnea, and hypoxia in setting of malignancy and coagulopathy,
   though pt has some "natural" anticoagulation on board from his disease
   process, as well as the defibrotide, and regardless, there are no
   therapeutic options for PE in this patient at this time.
   -Serial blood gases to guide vent setting management
   -Serial CXR to assess for pulmonary edema, infiltrate
   2) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Pt presenting w/ encephalopathy,
   coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Most likely etiology is severe VOD
   [**3-4**] auto BMT (specifically: cytotoxic chemotherapy-induced endothelial
   damage to the hepatic sinusoids and venules). Less likely acute viral
   hepatitis. Tbili continuing to trend up, now 5.2 this AM; all other
   LFTs trending down. The blood products required for correction of the
   coagulopathy present a significant volume challenge and worsen the
   ascities. Cardiac function is normal by ECHO, but even a normal heart
   is unlikely to be able to compensate for the combination of portal
   hypertension, third spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal
   function. Prognosis is extremely poor. GI and ID following.
   (a.) Hepatic Failure
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD
        -Plt>30
        -Hct>30
        -INR<1.5
        -Fibrinogen>150
   -Q6H plts
   -[**Hospital1 **] labs
   -Continue Albumin 75mg IV daily
   -Continue Acyclovir 400mg PO TID for HSV ppx
   -Continue Ganciclovir 230 mg IV Q12H (Day 1 = [**2155-4-10**]) for possible CMV
   infection
   -F/u viral hepatitis studies
   -Q2H FS to monitor for derangements in glucose metabolism
   -Consider liver transplant, per onc team (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**]
   (b.) Encephalopathy: Compounded by morphine on initial presentation. Pt
   now sedated on vent.
   -Lactulose 30mL PO QID per OGT
   (c.) Coagulopathy: [**3-4**] liver failure + cytotoxic chemotherapy +
   debifrotide side effects.
   -Continue to correct derangements with blood products (FFP, Plts, PRBC)
   per Defibrotide protocol
   (d.) Ascites: Tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively
   over course of ICU stay. Pt likely to have several liters of fluid in
   the belly. Concern for abdominal compartment syndrome.
   -Hold paracentesis for infectous risk, concern for fluid shifts (per
   onc)
   -Follow bladder pressure
   3.) Febrile Neutropenia: Pt persistently febrile with ANC of 0 on
   vancomycin, cefepime, micofungin. No identifiable infectious source.
   Urine cx negative. C diff negative. Blood cx NGTD. ID following.
   -Continue broad spectrum antimicrobials
   -Hold tylenol, for liver failure
   -Avoid all non-essential non-sterile procedures, including NGT, OGT,
   Foley placement
   4) [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 1.6, up from baseline of 0.8. Stable this AM. UOP 100cc/hr
   last night, down to approx 50cc/hr this AM. Etiology is ATN vs
   Hepatorenal syndrome. Urine lyes and sediment demonstrate Na<10 and
   granular casts. Per renal, ATN most likely [**3-4**] infection/hypotension.
   Acid/Base disturbance appears to be a hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
   w/ respiratory compensation. Renal following.
   -Trend BUN/Cr
   -Consider dialysis for fluid removal
   -Renally dose meds
   5) Mucositis: [**3-4**] chemotherapeutic regimen. Disrupted mucosal barrier
   may be site for bacterial translocation.
   -Continue caphasol, nystatin, gelclair
   6) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto BMT.
   -Filgrastim 480 mcg SC Q24H Start: Day +4 until ANC>1000
   -Ursodiol 600 mg PO QPM
   -Ursodiol 300 mg PO QAM
   -Ondansetron 8 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea/vomiting
   7) Electrolyes:
   -Potassium Phosphate Replacement (Oncology)  IV Sliding Scale
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TPN
   Glycemic Control:  FS Q2H

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous bone marrow transplant (auto BMT) and is now presenting with clinical and laboratory findings consistent with fulminant hepatic failure secondary to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). 

The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, which is likely caused by a combination of factors including V/Q mismatch, atelectasis, and possible pulmonary edema. There is also a concern for pulmonary embolism (PE), but there are no therapeutic options available at this time. 

The patient's hepatic failure is characterized by encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. The most likely etiology of the hepatic failure is severe VOD secondary to auto BMT. Less likely causes include acute viral hepatitis. 

The patient's coagulopathy has resulted in mucosal bleeding and requires correction with blood products. 

The patient's renal function is impaired, as indicated by an elevated creatinine level and granular casts in the urine. This could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or hepatorenal syndrome. 

The patient also has fever and neutropenia, which puts him at risk for infections. Broad-spectrum antimicrobials have been initiated. 

Other issues include hepatic encephalopathy, which is being managed with lactulose, and mucositis, which is being treated with muc

   aged male with NHL s/p auto transplant now day 9.  His course has been
   complicated by culture negative febrile neutropenia, VOD with hepatic
   failure, massive ascites, and respiratory failure requiring mechanical
   intubation.  Regarding respiratory failure, will increase peep to
   improve oxygenation and suspect this is secondary to low lung volumes
   and resp comp for metabolic acidosis.  Hepatic failure from VOD is
   being treated with experiemental drug requiring frequent labs to
   monitor for coagulopathy & thrombocytonia, fibrinogen and hct.  Also,
   mental status likely worsened secondary to HE and morphine.  Will
   minimize sedating meds.  Renal failure is stable.  Will discuss with
   hepatology re: stopping albumin given aggressive fluid challenges that
   he is getting from blood products.  Culture data remains negative on
   broad spectrum coverage and ID following.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) on day 9. He presented with culture-negative febrile neutropenia, severe sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS), massive ascites, and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, fulminant hepatic failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and renal failure. He has also experienced mucositis and electrolyte disturbances.

Assessment and Plan:
1) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has been successfully intubated after presenting with rapid shallow breathing, increased oxygen requirements, low lung volumes on chest X-ray, and serial arterial blood gases demonstrating respiratory fatigue. The etiology of hypoxia is likely severe atelectasis and ascites leading to shunt physiology. Possible components of pulmonary edema and volume overload are also considered, although the patient has no evidence of left ventricular dysfunction on echocardiogram. No evidence for pulmonary embolism is observed, given the tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia in the setting of malignancy and coagulopathy. Up-titrate PEEP to 11-14 to expand lung volumes and decrease FiO2 requirement. Re-check ABG on 500/14/10/60.

   Assessment and Plan:
   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 8 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11913**]
   transferred from BMT floor with clinical and laboratory findings
   consistent with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease.
   1) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt now s/p successful intubation after
   presenting w/ rapid shallow breathing, increased O2 requirements, low
   lung volumes on CXR [**3-4**] ascites, and serial ABGs demonstrating
   respiratory fatigue. Pt unable to tolerate BiPAP or shovel mask. +Blood
   in oropharynx [**3-4**] mucosal bleeding = aspiration risk. Respiratory
   alkalosis is compensatory for metabolic acidosis. Etiology of hypoxia
   is less clear. Most likely explanation is V/Q mismatch [**3-4**] atelectasis,
   with possible component of pulmonary edema [**3-4**] volume overload. No
   evidence for PNA on CXR. PE also a remote possibility, given
   tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia in setting of malignancy and
   coagulopathy, though pt has some "natural" anticoagulation on board
   from his disease process, as well as the defibrotide, and regardless,
   there are no therapeutic options for PE in this patient at this time.
   -Serial blood gases to guide vent setting management
   -Repeat CXR
   2) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Pt presenting w/ encephalopathy,
   coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Most likely etiology is VOD [**3-4**] auto
   BMT (specifically . Less likely acute viral hepatitis. LFTs continuing
   to trend up, with T Bili 5.2. Blood products required for correction of
   the coagulopathy present a significant volume challenge and worsen the
   ascities. Cardiac function is normal by ECHO, but even a normal heart
   is unlikely to be able to compensate for the combination of portal
   hypertension, third spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal
   function. GI and ID following.
   A) Hepatic Failure
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD
        -Plt>30
        -Hct>30
        -INR<1.5
        -Fibrinogen>150

   infection

   B) Encephalopathy: Compounded by morphine on initial presentation.
   -Lactulose 30mL PO QID per OGT (if placed)
   C) Ascites: Tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively over
   course of ICU stay. Pt likely to have several liters of fluid in the
   belly. Concern for abdominal compartment syndrome.
   -Hold paracentesis for infectous risk, concern for fluid shifts

   3.) Febrile Neutropenia: Pt persistently febrile with ANC of 0 on

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory distress with low lung volumes on the chest X-ray and increased O2 requirements. This may indicate a mismatch between ventilation and perfusion (V/Q mismatch), atelectasis, or pulmonary edema.

2. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient is showing signs of liver failure, including encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. The most likely cause is VOD (veno-occlusive disease) after an auto BMT (bone marrow transplant).

3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's mental status changes are compounded by morphine on initial presentation. Lactulose therapy is recommended to manage encephalopathy.

4. Ascites: The patient has tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively. There is a concern for abdominal compartment syndrome. Paracentesis is held due to infective risk and concern for fluid shifts.

5. Febrile Neutropenia: The patient is persistently febrile with an ANC (absolute neutrophil count) of 0. Broad-spectrum antimicrobials are being continued, and the patient is being followed by the ID (infectious diseases) team.

6. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's renal function is compromised, with stable creat

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who is currently in the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure secondary to VOD following an auto BMT. The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, requiring intubation. The patient also has massive ascites, encephalopathy, and coagulopathy. The patient's condition is complicated by multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and the potential for abdominal compartment syndrome.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration due to V/Q mismatch, atelectasis, and possible pulmonary edema. Close monitoring of blood gases and serial chest X-rays will be necessary to guide ventilator settings and assess for any worsening of pulmonary edema or infiltrates.

2. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient's liver function continues to deteriorate, leading to coagulopathy and encephalopathy. Continued monitoring of liver enzymes, bilirubin, and coagulation parameters is essential. Defibrotide therapy is being administered to manage VOD, and further evaluation for acute viral hepatitis is needed.

3. Massive Ascites: The patient has tense, massive ascites that worsens progressively. This can lead to abdominal compartment syndrome. Paracentesis may be required to relieve the pressure, but there is a risk of infective complications. Monitoring of bladder pressure and

   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 9 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT floor with clinical, laboratory, and radiographic
   findings consistent with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease.
   1) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt now s/p successful intubation after
   presenting w/ rapid shallow breathing, increased O2 requirements, low
   lung volumes on CXR [**3-4**] ascites, and serial ABGs demonstrating
   respiratory fatigue. Etiology of hypoxia is most likely severe
   atelectasis [**3-4**] ascites, leading to shunt physiology. Possible
   component of pulmonary edema [**3-4**] volume overload, though pt has no
   evidence of LV dysfunction on Echo. No evidence for PNA on CXR. PE also
   a remote possibility, given tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia in
   setting of malignancy and coagulopathy, though pt has some "natural"
   anticoagulation on board from his disease process, as well as the
   defibrotide, and regardless, there are no therapeutic options for PE in
   this patient at this time.
   -Up-titrate PEEP to [**11-14**] to expand lung volumes and decrease FiO2
   requirement
   -Re-check ABG on 500/14/10/60
   2) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Pt presenting w/ encephalopathy,
   coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Most likely explanation is severe
   VOD [**3-4**] auto BMT (specifically: cytotoxic chemotherapy-induced
   endothelial damage to the hepatic sinusoids and venules, which explains
   the reversal of flow in the portal vein but not the hepatic veins).
   Given hx of EtOH intake, pt may have underlying cirrhosis, not apparent
   on pre-SCT labs, which predisposed him to VOD. Less likely etiology for
   the liver failure is acute viral hepatitis; pt at risk [**3-4**]
   immunosuppression. Clinically, pt is worse this AM with an increased
   TBili to 5.2. The blood products required for correction of the
   coagulopathy present a significant volume challenge. Cardiac function
   is normal by ECHO, but even a normal heart is unlikely to be able to
   compensate for the combination of portal hypertension, third
   spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal function. Prognosis is
   extremely poor. GI following.
   (a.) Hepatic Failure
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD
        -Plt>30
        -Hct>30
        -INR<1.5
        -Fibrinogen>150
   -Q6H plts
   -[**Hospital1 **] labs
   -Consider d/c Albumin 75mg IV daily to reduce fluid intake
 discuss w/
   GI
   -Continue Ganciclovir 230 mg IV Q12H (Day 1 = [**2155-4-10**]) for possible HSV
   or CMV hepatitis
   -F/u viral hepatitis studies
   -Q2H FS to monitor for derangements in glucose metabolism
   -f/u GI recs
   -Monitor Is/Os
   (b.) Encephalopathy: Compounded by morphine on initial presentation. Pt
   now sedated on vent.
   -Lactulose 30mL PO QID per OGT
   (c.) Coagulopathy: [**3-4**] liver failure + cytotoxic chemotherapy +
   debifrotide side effects.
   -Continue to correct derangements with blood products (FFP, Plts, PRBC)
   per Defibrotide protocol
   -Continue Filgrastim 480 mcg SC Q24H Start: Day +4 until ANC>1000
   (d.) Ascites: Tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively
   over course of ICU stay with infusions of meds and blood products. Pt
   likely has several liters of fluid in his belly. Concern is for
   abdominal compartment syndrome and hepatorenal syndrome.
   -Hold paracentesis for infection risk, bleeding risk, concern for fluid
   shifts (per BMT and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**]
   -Follow bladder pressure
   3.) Febrile Neutropenia: Pt persistently febrile and tachycardic with
   ANC of 0 on vancomycin, cefepime, micofungin. No identifiable
   infectious source. Concern for SBP, per GI. Concern for bacterial
   translocation [**3-4**] mucositis. Urine cx negative. C diff negative. Blood
   cx NGTD. ID following.
   -Continue broad spectrum antimicrobials
   -Hold tylenol, for liver failure
   -Avoid all non-essential non-sterile procedures
   -f/u ID recs
   4) [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 1.6, up from baseline of 0.8. Stable this AM. UOP 100cc/hr
   last night, down to approx 50cc/hr this AM. Etiology is ATN vs
   Hepatorenal syndrome. Per renal, granular casts in urine sediment
   suggest ATN, likely [**3-4**] infection/hypotension. Hepatorenal may also be
   a contributing factor. Acid/Base disturbance appears to be a metabolic
   acidosis w/ respiratory compensation, likely [**3-4**] chemotherapy-induced
   distal RTA vs impaired ammonia generation in early renal failure.
   Dialysis not currently indicated but need may arise over the weekend if
   uremia develops or pt becomes oliguric. Renal is following and aware.
   -Trend BUN/Cr
   -Repeat urine lytes and urine [**Last Name (LF) 11924**], [**First Name3 (LF) 77**] renal recs
   -Renal US to r/o obstruction, per renal recs
   -Renally dose meds
   5) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT. Engraftment slower
   than expected.
   -Continue Filgrastim, as above
   -Consider steroids, per pt
s oncologist (Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 2355**]
   6) Mucositis: [**3-4**] chemotherapeutic regimen.
   -Continue caphasol, nystatin, gelclair
   7) Electrolyes:
   -Potassium Phosphate Replacement (Oncology)  IV Sliding Scale
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TPN, currently held for volume overload
   Glycemic Control:  FS Q2H

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been admitted to the ICU with clinical, laboratory, and radiographic findings consistent with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD (veno-occlusive disease). The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated rapidly, requiring intubation. He is also experiencing encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Other medical complications include febrile neutropenia, renal failure, and mucositis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely caused by severe atelectasis and ascites leading to shunt physiology. Pulmonary edema and pulmonary embolism are also possible but less likely.
2. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient's liver failure is most likely due to severe VOD following auto BMT (bone marrow transplantation). Underlying cirrhosis may also be a contributing factor. Prognosis is extremely poor.
3. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy is compounded by morphine use and now sedation on mechanical ventilation.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is due to liver failure, cytotoxic chemotherapy, and defibrotide side effects. Correction with blood products is necessary.
5. Ascites: The patient has tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively over the course of ICU stay.

   1) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt now s/p successful intubation after
   presenting w/ rapid shallow breathing, increased O2 requirements, low
   lung volumes on CXR [**3-4**] ascites, and serial ABGs demonstrating
   respiratory fatigue. Respiratory alkalosis is compensatory for
   metabolic acidosis [**3-4**] liver failure. Etiology of hypoxia is less
   clear. Most likely explanation is V/Q mismatch [**3-4**] atelectasis, with
   possible component of pulmonary edema [**3-4**] volume overload. No evidence
   for PNA on CXR. PE also a remote possibility, given tachycardia,
   tachypnea, and hypoxia in setting of malignancy and coagulopathy,
   though pt has some "natural" anticoagulation on board from his disease
   process, as well as the defibrotide, and regardless, there are no
   therapeutic options for PE in this patient at this time.
   -Serial blood gases to guide vent setting management
   -Serial CXR to assess for pulmonary edema, infiltrate
   2) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Pt presenting w/ encephalopathy,
   coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Most likely etiology is severe VOD
   [**3-4**] auto BMT (specifically: cytotoxic chemotherapy-induced endothelial
   damage to the hepatic sinusoids and venules). Less likely acute viral
   hepatitis. Tbili continuing to trend up, now 5.2 this AM; all other
   LFTs trending down. The blood products required for correction of the
   coagulopathy present a significant volume challenge and worsen the
   ascities. Cardiac function is normal by ECHO, but even a normal heart
   is unlikely to be able to compensate for the combination of portal
   hypertension, third spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal
   function. Prognosis is extremely poor. GI and ID following.
   (a.) Hepatic Failure
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD
        -Plt>30
        -Hct>30
        -INR<1.5
        -Fibrinogen>150
   -Q6H plts
   -[**Hospital1 **] labs
   -Continue Albumin 75mg IV daily
   -Continue Acyclovir 400mg PO TID for HSV ppx
   -Continue Ganciclovir 230 mg IV Q12H (Day 1 = [**2155-4-10**]) for possible CMV
   infection
   -F/u viral hepatitis studies
   -Q2H FS to monitor for derangements in glucose metabolism
   -Consider liver transplant, per onc team (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 356**]
   -Monitor Is/Os
   (b.) Encephalopathy: Compounded by morphine on initial presentation. Pt
   now sedated on vent.
   -Lactulose 30mL PO QID per OGT
   (c.) Coagulopathy: [**3-4**] liver failure + cytotoxic chemotherapy +
   debifrotide side effects.
   -Continue to correct derangements with blood products (FFP, Plts, PRBC)
   per Defibrotide protocol
   (d.) Ascites: Tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively
   over course of ICU stay. Pt likely to have several liters of fluid in
   the belly. Concern for abdominal compartment syndrome.
   -Hold paracentesis for infectous risk, concern for fluid shifts (per
   onc)
   -Follow bladder pressure
   3.) Febrile Neutropenia: Pt persistently febrile with ANC of 0 on
   vancomycin, cefepime, micofungin. No identifiable infectious source.
   Urine cx negative. C diff negative. Blood cx NGTD. ID following.
   -Continue broad spectrum antimicrobials
   -Hold tylenol, for liver failure
   -Avoid all non-essential non-sterile procedures, including NGT, OGT,
   Foley placement
   4) [**Last Name (un) **]: Cr 1.6, up from baseline of 0.8. Stable this AM. UOP 100cc/hr
   last night, down to approx 50cc/hr this AM. Etiology is ATN vs
   Hepatorenal syndrome. Urine lyes and sediment demonstrate Na<10 and
   granular casts. Per renal, ATN most likely [**3-4**] infection/hypotension.
   Acid/Base disturbance appears to be a hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
   w/ respiratory compensation. Renal following.
   -Trend BUN/Cr
   -Consider dialysis for fluid removal
   -Renally dose meds
   5) Mucositis: [**3-4**] chemotherapeutic regimen. Disrupted mucosal barrier
   may be site for bacterial translocation.
   -Continue caphasol, nystatin, gelclair
   6) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto BMT.
   -Filgrastim 480 mcg SC Q24H Start: Day +4 until ANC>1000
   -Ursodiol 600 mg PO QPM
   -Ursodiol 300 mg PO QAM
   -Ondansetron 8 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea/vomiting

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who was transferred to the ICU with clinical and laboratory findings consistent with fulminant hepatic failure. The patient presented with hypoxic respiratory failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. The most likely etiology of the hepatic failure is severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD) secondary to auto BMT. Other potential complications include hypoxic respiratory failure, febrile neutropenia, renal failure, mucositis, and electrolyte imbalances.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's rapid shallow breathing, increased O2 requirements, and low lung volumes on CXR suggest respiratory fatigue. 2. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient has encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Severe VOD secondary to auto BMT is the most likely cause, although acute viral hepatitis is a less likely alternative diagnosis. The prognosis is extremely poor.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and is currently in the ICU. The patient has been intubated for rising CO2 and worsening mental status. He has developed fulminant hepatic failure with coagulopathy, hypoxic respiratory failure, and massive ascites. The patient also has encephalopathy, febrile neutropenia, and renal failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's low lung volumes on CXR, ascites, and serial ABGs indicate respiratory fatigue. The etiology of hypoxia could be severe atelectasis, pulmonary edema, or pneumonia. Mechanical ventilation and careful monitoring are necessary.
2. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient presents with encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and massive ascites. The likely cause is severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD) after auto-SCT. Other possible etiologies include acute viral hepatitis. Management includes defibrotide, careful fluid balance, and monitoring for derangements in glucose metabolism.
3. Encephalopathy: The patient's mental status changes are compounded by morphine on initial presentation. Sedation on ventilation and lactulose therapy are recommended. Head CT is negative.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has deranged coagulation parameters

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 57-year-old male with a history of follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous bone marrow transplant (AutoBMT) 10 days ago. He is currently admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and fulminant hepatic failure, possibly secondary to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient also has worsening renal failure and requires dialysis. His white blood cell (WBC) count is increasing, indicating movement towards engraftment.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which requires mechanical ventilation support. The treatment goal is to maintain adequate oxygenation and effective ventilation. The increase in PEEP has shown an improvement in lung volumes and oxygenation. Further increase in PEEP may be necessary if bladder pressure and abdominal distention worsen.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). A dialysis catheter has been placed, and the patient remains anuric. Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) will be attempted for fluid removal and renal replacement therapy.

3. Hepatic Encephalopathy/Hepatic Failure with VOD: The patient has hepatic encephalopathy and hepatic failure associated with VOD. Treatment includes lactulose, ursodeoxycholic acid (UCA), and defibrotide as per protocol.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT and is now in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient presented with fulminant hepatic failure, acute renal failure, hypoxic respiratory failure, and possible underlying cirrhosis. He also has coagulopathy, massive ascites, and elevated liver function tests. The patient's prognosis remains extremely poor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Acute Renal Failure: The patient is anuric overnight with a creatinine level of 3.2. Ischemic ATN is suspected as the etiology, possibly due to hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD). CVVH is being continued to manage renal function.

2) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to restrictive physiology, increased intra-abdominal pressure, mental status changes, and concern for volume overload. FiO2 is being lowered to 40% and PEEP is being dropped to 10.

3) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The etiology is severe VOD post-splenectomy. The patient presented with encephalopathy, massive ascites, coagulopathy, and elevated liver function tests. Prognosis remains poor.

4) Coagulopathy: Liver failure, cytotoxic chemotherapy, and defibrotide side effects are contributing factors. Blood products are being given to correct derangements.

5) Ascites: The patient's ascites has improved, but there is still concern for abdominal compartment syndrome. Paracentesis is being held due to infection risk, bleeding risk, and concern for fluid shifts.

6) Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy is likely due to hepatic failure and/or uremia. Lactulose and frequent monitoring of blood glucose levels are being used to manage this condition.

7) Shock: The patient has hypoperfusion and decreased effective circulating volume secondary to liver failure. Norepinephrine is being used to maintain MAP between 65-75.

8) Febrile Neutropenia: Resolved, but the patient is still on antiviral prophylaxis due to recent chemotherapy.

9) Follicular Lymphoma: The patient recently underwent BEAM auto SCT and is recovering. BMT is following up on the patient's progress.

10) Gut Function: The patient is recovering gut function and has passed stool. PO medications are being resumed.

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant on day 11. He was transferred to the ICU from the BMT unit with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. The patient now presents with acute renal failure on CVVH, hypoxic respiratory failure, and fulminant hepatic failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has worsened, leading to anuria and elevated creatinine levels. Ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is suspected, possibly as a component of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). CVVH will continue with a target filtration rate of 100-150cc/hr once the patient is off pressors.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to severe atelectasis and shunt physiology caused by ascites. PEEP has been up-titrated to 15 and FiO2 to 50. The goal is to wean PEEP to 10 and lower FiO2 to 40 while monitoring ABG results.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who is currently in the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure and acute renal failure on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH). The patient has a history of bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and is experiencing severe sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (VOD) as the etiology of his hepatic failure. He also has underlying cirrhosis and a history of alcohol abuse. The patient presented with encephalopathy, massive ascites, coagulopathy, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). Initial abdominal ultrasound (US) showed no flow through the portal vein, which was compatible with thrombosis or slow/stagnant flow. Repeat US yesterday showed no flow through the portal vein, with increased ascites. The patient's prognosis remains extremely poor.

The patient has multiple complications including hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and fulminant hepatic failure. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with PEEP at 15 and FiO2 at 50 due to severe atelectasis and ascites causing shunt physiology. The etiology of hypoxia is most likely severe atelectasis and ascites. The patient's respiratory status is stable overall.

In terms of medical complications, the patient has acute renal failure, which is ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN). He is anuric overnight, but his creatinine

Summary:
Summary:
- The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent auto-SCT on day 11.
- He presented with fulminant hepatic failure, acute renal failure, and hypoxic respiratory failure.
- The patient has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation.
- He has been diagnosed with VOD, ATN, and severe atelectasis causing shunt physiology.
- The patient's prognosis is extremely poor due to the combination of portal hypertension, third spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient is experiencing severe liver dysfunction, which can lead to encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and ascites. Prognosis for recovery is poor.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's liver failure, along with the effects of chemotherapy and defibrotide, has resulted in coagulopathy. Blood product transfusions may be required to correct the coagulation abnormalities.
3. Ascites: The patient has massive ascites that has worsened progressively. There is concern for abdominal compartment syndrome and hepatorenal syndrome. Paracentesis may be considered if bladder pressures increase and urine output continues to fall.
4. Febrile Neutropenia: Despite being off broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient remains febrile and tachycardic. No identifiable infectious source has been found. There is concern for SBP and bacterial translocation due to mucositis. ID follow-up is necessary.
5. Follicular Lymphoma: The patient is post-BEAM auto-SCT, day 11, and is engrafting. Filigrastim has been stopped as the ANC is greater than 1000.
6. Mucositis: The patient is experiencing chemotherapeutic-induced mucositis. Oral care measures such as caphasol, nystatin, and gelclair should be continued.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient requires close monitoring and management of electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium and phosphate.
8. Line-Related Complications: The patient has multiple lines in place, including an arterial line, dialysis catheter, and multi-lumen line. Regular assessment for complications such as infection or thrombosis is necessary.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the information provided in the progress note.

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who presented with fulminant hepatic failure secondary to severe VOD post BEAM auto SCT. The patient has also developed acute renal failure, hypoxic respiratory failure, and coagulopathy. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hepatic Failure: The patient's prognosis remains extremely poor due to severe VOD. Close monitoring of liver function tests, electrolytes, and coagulation profile is necessary. Defibrotide has been initiated per protocol for VOD management.

2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation status is compromised due to liver failure, cytotoxic chemotherapy, and defibrotide side effects. Regular monitoring and correction of derangements with blood products will be required.

3. Ascites: The patient has tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively over the course of ICU stay. There is concern for abdominal compartment syndrome and hepatorenal syndrome. Paracentesis may be considered if bladder pressures increase and urine output continues to fall.

4. Febrile Neutropenia: Although the patient is no longer febrile or neutropenic, there is a concern for SBP and bacterial translocation due to mucositis. Broad spectrum antimicrobials should be continued, and the patient should avoid non-essential non-sterile procedures.

5. Follicular Lymphoma: The patient is status post BE

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent auto-SCT (stem cell transplantation) and is now presenting with multiple medical complications. He has acute renal failure, hypoxic respiratory failure, fulminant hepatic failure, coagulopathy, and potential mucositis. The patient is also at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated at 3.2 mg/dL, indicating impaired renal function. CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) is being used to manage the renal failure. The etiology is unclear but could be due to either acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or hepatorenal syndrome. Further evaluation is needed to determine the exact cause and potential need for dialysis.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated due to increased oxygen requirements, low lung volumes on chest X-ray, and serial ABGs (arterial blood gases) demonstrating respiratory fatigue. The likely etiology of hypoxia is severe atelectasis and shunt physiology caused by ascites. Other possible contributing factors include pulmonary edema and potential pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient's PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) has been adjusted, and re-checking of ABG later today is planned.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant on day 11 and was transferred to the ICU from BMT due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by VOD. The patient also has acute renal failure on CVVH, hypoxic respiratory failure, and is intubated. The patient's current condition is stable with some improvements in lab values, but the prognosis remains extremely poor. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is on CVVH for acute worsening in renal function. The etiology of renal failure is uncertain, with possibilities including ATN or hepatorenal syndrome. Renal US did not show any obstruction. The patient's electrolytes have improved, and further monitoring of BUN/Cr, Is/Os, and trends in electrolytes are recommended. Medications should be dosed accordingly, and follow-up with the renal team is advised.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation with PEEP at 15 and FiO2 at 50. The etiology of hypoxia is most likely severe atelectasis and ascites leading to shunt physiology. The plan is to maintain PEEP at 15 and lower FiO2 to 40 while rechecking ABG. 

3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The etiology is severe VOD post-sCT

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) and is now presenting with multiple medical complications. The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications include:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has worsening renal function and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). The cause of acute renal failure could be either acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's creatinine level is stable, and there are no signs of obstruction on renal ultrasound.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and requires increased oxygenation due to severe atelectasis and shunt physiology. The patient's PaO2 is 87 on a FiO2 of 50, and PEEP has been increased to 15 cmH2O.

3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient has severe sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS), previously known as veno-occlusive disease (VOD), which is a complication of stem cell transplantation. This has resulted in encephalopathy, massive ascites, coagulopathy, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). The prognosis remains extremely poor.

4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy due to liver failure, cytotoxic chemotherapy, and side effects of defibrotide. Blood products, specifically

   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 11 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT floor with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**]
   [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease, now with acute renal failure on CVVH.
   1) Acute Renal Failure: Cr 3.2, stable from yesterday. UOP 10-20cc/hr
   last night, down from approx 100cc/hr on admission. Etiology is ATN vs
   Hepatorenal syndrome. Renal US negative for obstruction. Per renal,
   granular casts in urine sediment suggest ATN, likely [**3-4**]
   infection/hypotension. Hepatorenal may also be a contributing factor.
   Acid/Base disturbance appears to be a metabolic acidosis w/ respiratory
   compensation, likely [**3-4**] chemotherapy-induced distal RTA vs impaired
   ammonia generation in early renal failure. Dialysis not currently
   indicated but need may arise over the weekend if uremia develops or pt
   becomes oliguric. Renal is following and aware.
   -Continue CVVH
   -Trend BUN/Cr
   -Renal US to r/o obstruction negative.
   -Renally dose meds
   -Patient will likely need CVVH.
   2) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated on [**4-10**] for increased O2
   requirements, low lung volumes on CXR [**3-4**] ascites, and serial ABGs
   demonstrating respiratory fatigue. Etiology of hypoxia is most likely
   severe atelectasis [**3-4**] ascites, leading to shunt physiology. Possible
   component of pulmonary edema [**3-4**] volume overload, though pt has no
   evidence of LV dysfunction on Echo. ?PNA on CXR. PE also a remote
   possibility, given tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia in setting of
   malignancy and coagulopathy, though pt has some "natural"
   anticoagulation on board from his disease process, as well as the
   defibrotide, and regardless, there are no therapeutic options for PE in
   this patient at this time. Overnight, uptitrated PEEP from 10 to 15
   and FiO2 from 40 to 50 for PaO2 of 75-83, now improved at 86.
   -Re-check ABG later today.
   3) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Pt presenting w/ encephalopathy,
   coagulopathy, and massive ascites. Most likely explanation is severe
   VOD [**3-4**] auto-SCT. Given hx of EtOH intake, pt may have underlying
   cirrhosis, not apparent on pre-SCT labs, which predisposed him to VOD.
   Less likely etiology for the liver failure is acute viral hepatitis; pt
   at risk [**3-4**] immunosuppression. Clinically, pt is worse this AM with an
   increased TBili from 5.2
 10. The blood products required for
   correction of the coagulopathy present a significant volume challenge.
   Cardiac function is normal by ECHO, but even a normal heart is unlikely
   to be able to compensate for the combination of portal hypertension,
   third spacing/interstitial edema, and diminished renal function.
   Prognosis is extremely poor. Hepatology, renal, and ID following.

    (c.) Ascites: Tense, massive ascites that has worsened progressively

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant 11 days ago. He was transferred to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure secondary to hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD) and is now experiencing acute renal failure. The patient has been intubated and is on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) for acute respiratory failure, which is likely caused by severe atelectasis and ascites. The patient also has coagulopathy, massive ascites, and encephalopathy, indicating fulminant hepatic failure. Prognosis is extremely poor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to severe atelectasis and ascites. There may be a component of pulmonary edema, although the patient does not have evidence of left ventricular dysfunction on Echo. Possible causes include pneumonia or pulmonary embolism, although these are remote possibilities.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has elevated creatinine levels and is on CVVH. The etiology of renal failure is between acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and hepatorenal syndrome. Renal US did not show any obstruction. Dialysis may be needed over the weekend if uremia develops or the patient becomes oliguric.

3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The patient's liver

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation on day 11. He was transferred to the ICU from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, now with acute renal failure on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). The patient has several medical complications, including hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and fulminant hepatic failure.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for severe atelectasis, increased intra-abdominal pressure, ascites, and concern for volume overload. PEEP has been up-titrated to 15 and FiO2 to 50 with PaO2 87 on this morning's ABG. The plan is to maintain PEEP at 15, lower FiO2 to 40, and re-check ABG. If okay, drop PEEP to 10.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is anuric overnight with a creatinine level of 3.2, stable from yesterday. Electrolytes have improved. Ischemic ATN is the suspected etiology, possibly a component of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). CVVH with net 0 filtration once off pressors, net 100-150cc/hr, is being continued. Trends in lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os are to be monitored. Medications are being dosed for CVVH, and renal recommendations are being followed.

3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The etiology is severe VOD post stem cell transplantation (SCT). There is also a possibility of underlying cirrhosis due to EtOH history. Viral hepatitis is unlikely, given negative labs. The patient presented with encephalopathy, massive ascites, coagulopathy, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and initial abdominal ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reversal of flow through the portal vein. Repeat abdominal US yesterday showed no flow through the portal vein, with increased ascites. Prognosis remains extremely poor. Hepatology, renal, and infectious disease (ID) teams are following the patient.

The patient's current medications include norepinephrine, potassium chloride (KCl), calcium gluconate (CRRT), fentanyl, propofol, and other ICU medications. He has a history of allergies to penicillins and hives.

Physical examination findings include the patient being intubated, sedated, appearing jaundiced, with dullness to percussion and positive bowel sounds (BS) in the abdomen. There is pitting edema to the thighs. Extremities are warm and well-perfused, with distal pulses 2+ on the left and 1+ on the right.

Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes (ALT

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male on day 11 following an auto-BMT for lymphoma. He is now complicated by VOD and has been started on CVVH. Antibiotics have been discontinued with evidence of resolution of acute infection. The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, acute renal failure secondary to ATN, and hepatic encephalopathy. The patient's condition includes restriction from abdominal compartment, volume overload, abdominal pressures, and mental status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has respiratory failure due to restriction from abdominal compartment, which may be improving. Barriers to extubation include volume overload, abdominal pressures, and mental status. The plan includes propofol/fentanyl for sedation, adequate PEEP, and continued full support while looking to support hepatic and renal failure. A trial decrease in FiO2 to 0.40 will be monitored.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure secondary to ATN. CVVH will continue, and I/O will remain even. Bladder pressure is acceptable, and efforts will be made to move to a negative fluid balance today at 100cc/hr if MAP >80 off of levophed.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: There is concern for worsening CNS status in the setting of persistent altered mental status. Monitoring for cerebral edema will be done. The plan includes restarting lactulose to aid in improvement

   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 11 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**]
   [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease, now with acute renal failure on CVVH.
    1) Acute Renal Failure: Pt started on CVVH [**2155-4-12**] for worsening
   metabolic acidosis and worsening renal function. Acidemia improved
   today. Anuric overnight. Cr 3.2 this morning, stable from yesterday.
   Electrolytes improved. Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine sediment w/
   muddy brown casts). Possible component of HRS. Renal US negative for
   obstruction. Renal is following.
   -Continue CVVH w/ citrate: goal = net 0 filtration
 once off pressors,
   net  filter 100-150cc/hr (per renal recs)
   -Trend lytes, serum osms, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   -Fundoscopic exam, Q1H pupil checks to assess for rising ICP; mannitol
   at bedside for PRN use
   -Dose meds for CVVH
   2) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**] for worsening hypoxia
   and respiratory fatigue. Overall stable this AM. Lung volumes improved
   on CXR. PEEP at 15 and FiO2 at 50% with PaO2 87 on ABG. Pt remains
   intubated for a) restrictive physiology [**3-4**] increased intra-abdominal
   pressure [**3-4**] ascites (improved today), b) mental status changes [**3-4**]
   encephalopathy, c) concern for volume overload.
    -Lower FiO2 to 40%
 re-check ABG; if okay, drop PEEP to 10
   -Hold paracentesis, pending improvement in other parameters keeping
   patient on vent
   3) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Etiology is severe VOD [**3-4**] SCT. Possible
   underlying cirrhosis [**3-4**] EtOH history. Viral hepatitis unlikely, given
   negative labs to date. Pt presented w/ encephalopathy, massive ascites,
   coagulopathy, elevated LFTs. Initial abd US and MRI
 reversal of flow
   through portal vein. Repeat abd US [**4-12**]
 no flow through portal vein,
   increased ascites. Pt clinically stable. LFTs slightly improved after
   peaking yesterday: T Bili 8.0, down from 10.0. Prognosis remains
   extremely poor. Hepatology, Renal, and ID following.
    (a.) VOD
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD (targets for admin:
   Plt>30, Hct>30, INR<1.5, Fibrinogen>150)
   -Q6H labs, as necessary, to monitor defibrotide parameters
   (b.) Coagulopathy: [**3-4**] liver failure + cytotoxic chemotherapy +
   debifrotide side effects.
   -Continue to correct derangements with blood products (FFP, Plts, PRBC)
   per Defibrotide protocol
    (c.) Ascites: Improved today. Bladder pressure 27mmHg overnight,
   16mmHg this AM. Concern is still for abdominal compartment syndrome.
   Have been holding paracentesis for infection risk, bleeding risk,
   concern for fluid shifts.
   -Continue to monitor bladder pressure
   -Paracentesis if bladder pressure > 20-25, given reduced concern for
   infection (ANC>7000), bleeding (Plts>50)

   (d) Encephalopathy: [**3-4**] hepatic failure +/- uremia.
   -Lactulose 30 mL PO/NG QID
   -Q4H FS to monitor for derangements in glucose metabolism
   4) Shock: Hypoperfusion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume in
   setting of liver failure. Norepinephrine started to maintain MAP>65.
   Clinically improved today. Stable BPs >100/60. Lactate 3.7, down from
   5.6.
   -Down-titrate norepinephrine; maintain MAP 65-75.

   negative to date. Abx stopped. ID following.

   -f/u culture data
   6) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 11. Pt is
   engrafting per BMT. Received IV solumedrol x1 for anti-inflammatory
   effect. Filigrastim stopped [**4-12**] for ANC>1000. BMT following.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) on day 11. He was transferred to the ICU from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD), now with acute renal failure on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH). The patient's current conditions include hypoxic respiratory failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and potential abdominal compartment syndrome.

Medical Complications:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has worsening renal function with metabolic acidosis and anuria overnight. His creatinine level is stable at 3.2 mg/dL. The etiology is ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with muddy brown casts. The patient's electrolytes have improved, but he remains on CVVH with a goal of net filtration between 100-150 cc/hr. Renal US negative for obstruction.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient intubated for worsening hypoxia and respiratory fatigue. His PaO2 is 87 on ABG, and he is on a FiO2 of 50% with PEEP at 15 cmH2O. The patient remains intubated due to restrictive physiology, increased intra-abdominal pressure, mental status changes, and concern for volume overload.

3. Fulminant

 once off pressors,

 re-check ABG; if okay, drop PEEP to 10

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) on day 11. He presented with fulminant hepatic failure due to severe VOD post-SCT and possible underlying cirrhosis. The patient also has acute renal failure on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with muddy brown casts indicative of ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Other complications include hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's worsening renal function and metabolic acidosis necessitated CVVH. It is important to monitor electrolyte levels, serum osmolality, BUN/Cr ratio, and Is/Os balance. The goal for CVVH filtration should be set at 100-150 cc/hr. Fundoscopic exam and Q1H pupil checks should be performed to assess for rising intracranial pressure (ICP). Mannitol should be available for PRN use.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to restrictive physiology, increased intra-abdominal pressure, ascites, and encephalopathy. FiO2 should be lowered to 40% and re-checked ABG. If the ABG is acceptable, PEEP can be reduced to 10

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of lymphoma who underwent bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and is now experiencing persistent VOD/hepatic failure, renal failure, and respiratory failure. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 118/76 to 136/78 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on ventilator support. 

The patient is currently on various medications, including fentanyl for pain management, norepinephrine for hemodynamic support, calcium gluconate and potassium chloride through continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and other ICU medications. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST), bilirubin levels, and lactate levels. The blood count reveals a decreased platelet count. The electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for low potassium and magnesium. 

The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins and has received several antibiotics recently. 

In terms of physical examination, the patient is sedated and minimally responsive to stimuli. The endotracheal tube is in place, and the patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cm

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto transplant on day 12. He was transferred to the ICU from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure and acute renal failure on CVVH. The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, ascites, and potential abdominal compartment syndrome.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is severely oliguric, and there is a possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) due to liver failure. Close monitoring of renal function and electrolytes is necessary.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and unable to wean FiO2 below 50%. Restrictive physiology, increased intra-abdominal pressure, mental status changes, and volume overload are contributing factors. Current ventilator settings should be maintained.
3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Etiology is severe VOD post-sCT, with possible underlying cirrhosis. The patient's prognosis remains extremely poor. Hepatology, renal, and ID teams should follow up on the patient's condition.
4. Coagulopathy: Liver failure, cytotoxic chemotherapy, and defibrotide side effects are contributing to the coagulopathy. Correction of derangements with blood products should be done per defibrotide protocol.
5. Ascites: The patient

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred to the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure due to severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD), acute renal failure on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient's condition remains critical, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) involving the liver, kidneys, lungs, and possibly the brain.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hepatic encephalopathy: Given the patient's fulminant hepatic failure and elevated liver enzymes, there is a risk of hepatic encephalopathy. This can be monitored through neuropsychiatric assessments and lab tests such as ammonia levels.

2. Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS): The patient's acute renal failure may progress to HRS, which is a type of kidney failure associated with advanced liver disease. Monitoring of renal function and urine output is crucial.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters and adjustment of ventilator settings will be necessary.

4. Infection: The patient is at high risk of developing infections due to immunosuppression from chemotherapy and prolonged intubation. Frequent monitoring of vital signs, white blood cell count

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He is currently admitted to the ICU for ongoing management and stabilization. The patient's condition remains critical, and he continues to require mechanical ventilation and vasoactive infusions. Notable recent events include an episode of bilious vomiting, increased FiO2 requirement, and the need for increased sedation. Renal replacement therapy is being considered due to worsening renal function. There are also concerns regarding possible pulmonary embolism and the need for further investigation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is deteriorating, as indicated by the increasing serum creatinine levels and oliguria. Close monitoring and consideration of renal replacement therapy may be necessary.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of immobilization and the presence of risk factors make pulmonary embolism a potential complication. Further investigation, such as a repeat right upper quadrant ultrasound, is recommended to evaluate for possible pulmonary embolism.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein levels suggest an ongoing infection. Cultures and appropriate antimicrobial therapy should be considered to prevent or treat any potential infections.
4. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and coagulopathy indicate possible hepatic dysfunction. Continued monitoring of liver function and appropriate management are crucial.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been admitted to the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure and acute oliguric renal failure. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient's condition remains critical, with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome involving the liver, kidneys, lungs, and gastrointestinal system.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient is dependent on vasopressors for blood pressure support, indicating possible hypotension. This may be a result of liver failure, vasodilatory effects of sedation, preload depression, or other factors. Close monitoring of blood pressure and titration of vasopressor support is necessary.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has oliguric renal failure and is on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH). The cause of kidney injury is believed to be ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with possible hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD) contributing to hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). Continued CVVH with appropriate fluid management is crucial.
3. Fulminant Hepatic Failure: The etiology of hepatic failure is severe VOD post-stem cell transplantation (SCT), with possible underlying cirrhosis. The patient presents with encephalopathy, massive ascites, coagulopathy, and elevated liver function

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male who is on day 13 post auto-BMT (bone marrow transplant) with persistent respiratory, renal, and hepatic failure. He has had persistent alteration in mental status and now has reasonable stability of bladder pressure and abdominal exam with mild increase in FIO2 requirement as sedation was weaned.

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided are:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure with significant chest wall restriction due to an abdominal process and likely ascites. The physician plans to move to more optimal PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining fluid balance. If there is no improvement in oxygenation and blood pressure is negatively affected, they will decrease PEEP to 12 and re-evaluate PaO2.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, and the physician will continue with CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) to maintain I/O even goal and look to move to small amounts of hemofiltration.

3. Hepatic Failure/Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient has hepatic failure with hepatic encephalopathy, and the physician will work to maintain MAP (mean arterial pressure) at 65, continue to follow the exam, trial lactulose, minimize sedation, and continue defibrotide while awaiting final interpretation from radiology on implications of findings for flow. They also need to consider adding rifax

   acidosis and worsening renal function. Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts). Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome. Acidemia stable with CVVH but pt
   remains severely oliguric. Could not tolerate volume removal [**3-4**]
   hypotension. Renal is following.

   5) Leukocytosis: [**3-4**] filgrastim (unlikely, per BMT) versus new

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who presented with fulminant hepatic failure and is currently in the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure, pressor support, and acute renal failure. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 15 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. He has a history of recent BEAM auto SCT and is now showing signs of severe VOD. The patient's current medications include cefepime, vancomycin, acyclovir, calcium gluconate (CRRT), fentanyl, KCl (CRRT), propofol, and norepinephrine.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypotension: The patient has increased pressor requirement, indicating possible persistent hypotension. Factors contributing to hypotension may include decreased effective circulating volume due to liver failure, vasodilation, preload depression, and high PEEP.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for restrictive physiology (ascites), mental status changes (encephalopathy), and concern for volume overload. There is a possibility of auto-PEEP due to over-breathing the vent. The patient should be switched to pressure support ventilation (PSV) and daily chest X-rays should be done.

3. Ileus: The patient has low stool output, high residuals, and possible stool on suctioning

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure, requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) for acute respiratory failure, ventilator support for hypoxic respiratory failure, and pressor support for hypotension.

The patient's current condition includes hypotension, hypoxic respiratory failure, ileus, oliguric acute renal failure (ARF), leukocytosis, hyperglycemia, and fulminant hepatic failure. The etiology of the hepatic failure is severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD) post SCT, with possible underlying cirrhosis.

The plan includes continuing antibiotics until blood, urine, and sputum cultures return negative, attempting to down-titrate norepinephrine with mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65 and systolic blood pressure (SBP) >85, attempting to wean sedation, switching to pressure support ventilation (PSV) given the patient's spontaneous respiratory rate (RR) >14, holding paracentesis pending improvement in other parameters while keeping the patient on ventilator support, and aggressive bowel regimen for ileus.

Additionally, the patient is on CVVH without volume removal, cefepime and vancomycin dosed for CVVH, defibrotide for VOD, ursodiol via oral gastric tube

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure, hypoxic respiratory failure, and hypotension. The patient has been on ventilator support, CVVH for acute respiratory failure, and pressor support for hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's increased pressor requirement suggests a potential complication of hypotension. This could be due to decreased effective circulating volume, vasodilation, sedation, preload depression, high PEEP, sepsis, or adrenal insufficiency. Further evaluation and management are necessary.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to restrictive physiology (ascites), mental status changes (encephalopathy), and concern for volume overload. Daily CXR and aggressive bowel regimen are needed.

3. Ileus: The patient's low stool output, high residuals, and concern for stool on suctioning indicate the possibility of ileus. A KUB showed no evidence of bowel obstruction, so further evaluation is needed.

4. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient started on CVVH for worsening metabolic acidosis and renal function. Severe oliguria persists despite CVVH, and careful monitoring of electrolytes, BUN/Cr, Is/O

   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 14 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**]
   [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease, requiring CVVH for ARF, ventilator support for
   hypoxic respiratory failure, and pressor support for hypotension.
   1) Hypotension: Pt with increased pressor requirement over past 24
   hours. Hypotension most likely due to decreased effective circulating
   volume [**3-4**] liver failure, vasodilation [**3-4**] sedation, and preload
   depression [**3-4**] high PEEP. Other possible factors include sepsis (pt had
   new leukocytosis off abx that improved after abx re-started, cx data
   pending) vs adrenal insufficiency (unlikely given hyperglycemia).
   -Check Cortisol
   -Continue antibiotics until blood, urine, and sputum cultures return
   negative
   -Attempt to down-titrate norepinephrine w/ MAP>65, SBP>85
   -Attempt to wean sedation
   2) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**] for worsening hypoxia
   and respiratory fatigue. Pt remains intubated for a) restrictive
   physiology [**3-4**] ascites (slightly worse [**4-16**], given increased
   atelectasis on CXR), b) mental status changes [**3-4**] encephalopathy, c)
   concern for volume overload. PEEP appears adequate based on compliance
   curve, though possible that effective PEEP @ level of the alveoli is
   less than 15 secondary to increased intra-abdominal pressure. This
   morning, pt is over-breathing the vent, adding possible component of
   auto-PEEP.
   -Switch to PSV, given pt with spontaneous RR >14
   -Hold paracentesis, pending improvement in other parameters keeping
   patient on vent
   -Daily CXR
   3) Ileus: Low stool output, high residuals, ?stool on suctioning,
   reduced bowel sounds all concerning for ileus in the setting of
   critical illness and ascites. KUB negative for obstruction.
   -Aggressive bowel regimen
   -Hold TFs until pt is moving bowels
   -Reglan for nausea/vomiting
    4) Oliguric ARF: Pt started on CVVH [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function. Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts) with possible component of hepatorenal
   syndrome. Acidemia resolved on CVVH but pt remains severely oliguric.
   Could not tolerate volume removal [**3-4**] hypotension. Renal is following.
   -Continue current CVVH w/o volume removal
   -Trend lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   -Q1H pupil checks to r/o herniation
   -Dose meds for CVVH
   5) Leukocytosis: [**3-4**] filgrastim (unlikely, per BMT) versus new
   infection, given that rise correlated w/ cessation of initial
   antibiotics, though pt was culture negative at that time. WBC trending
   down today on abx. Difficult to interpret fever curve, given CVVH. No
   evidence of biliary infection on RUQ US. No evidence of PNA on CXR. ID
   following.
   -Continue Vanc/Cefepime, dosed for CVVH
   -f/u blood, sputum, urine cultures
   -Consider paracentesis to r/o SBP if hypotension and leukocytosis
   persist
   6) Hyperglycemia: FS BS 225-369 yesterday with 10 units Regular in TPN
   + Humalog Sliding Scale.
   -f/u TPN recs
   -Adjust ISS
   7) Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Etiology is severe VOD [**3-4**] SCT. Possible
   underlying cirrhosis [**3-4**] EtOH history. Viral hepatitis unlikely, given
   negative labs to date. Pt presented w/ encephalopathy, massive ascites,
   coagulopathy, elevated LFTs. RUQ US on [**4-14**] demonstrated persistent
   reversal of flow in main portal vein. LFTs trending down; TBili 7
   today, down from peak of 10. Hepatology following.
    (a.) VOD: Can resolve with defibrotide as little as one week; more
   common is 3 wks to 3 months.
   -Defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD (targets for admin:
   Plt>30, Hct>30, INR<1.5, Fibrinogen>150)
   -Urusodiol via OGT
   -Q6H labs, as necessary, to monitor defibrotide parameters
   -f/u HSV serology
   (b.) Coagulopathy: [**3-4**] liver failure + cytotoxic chemotherapy +
   debifrotide side effects.
   -Continue to correct derangements with blood products (FFP, Plts, PRBC)
   per Defibrotide protocol
    (c.) Ascites: Stable. Bladder pressures <20mmHg. Have been holding
   paracentesis for infection risk, bleeding risk, concern for fluid
   shifts.
   -Monitor Bladder Pressure to r/o abdominal compartment syndrome
   -Paracentesis for persistently elevated (>25) bladder pressure
   -Perform tap 2 hrs after defibrotide dose, per BMT
   (d) Encephalopathy: [**3-4**] hepatic failure +/- uremia.
   -Lactulose
 PR administration, given pt not tolerating TFs
   -Consider adding rifaximin once pt tolerating TFs
   -Q6H FS to monitor for derangements in glucose metabolism
   8) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 13. Pt has

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant and was transferred to the ICU from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure, requiring CVVH for ARF, ventilator support for hypoxic respiratory failure, and pressor support for hypotension. The patient's condition has not improved, and he continues to require life support measures. Potential medical complications include hypotension, hypoxic respiratory failure, ileus, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, hyperglycemia, fulminant hepatic failure, and complications related to the underlying follicular lymphoma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's increased pressor requirement suggests ongoing hypotension. Possible causes include decreased effective circulating volume due to liver failure, vasodilation, preload depression, high PEEP, sepsis, or adrenal insufficiency. Further evaluation and management are required.

2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for restrictive physiology (ascites), mental status changes (encephalopathy), and concern for volume overload. Daily CXR and weaning of sedation should be considered.

3. Ileus: The patient shows signs of ileus, including low stool output, high residuals, and possible stool on suctioning. A bowel regimen and holding tube feeds until bowel movement are recommended.

4. Oliguric Acute Renal

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male who underwent a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and is now experiencing multiple organ failure including respiratory, renal, and hepatic failure. The patient's condition is complicated by VOD (veno-occlusive disease), which has led to hepatic failure. The patient also has a history of lymphoma and is currently being managed by the BMT team.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 99/66 mmHg to 126/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a ventilator mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), hematocrit (Hct), platelet count (Plt), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine (Cr), and liver enzymes (ALT/AST). Imaging studies reveal ascites without obstruction and small bilateral atelectasis on chest X-ray.

Summary of the Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who is day 15 post BEAM Auto stem cell transplant. He was transferred to the ICU from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure, ARF requiring CVVH, ventilator support for hypoxic respiratory failure, and pressor support for hypotension. The patient's current conditions include leukocytosis, hypotension, hypoxic respiratory failure, ileus, altered mental status, hepatic failure, metabolic acidosis, oliguric ARF, hyperglycemia, and follicular lymphoma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has increased despite antibiotic coverage. Possible sources of infection include Clostridium difficile (C diff), spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), line infection, or pancreatitis. Further diagnostic work-up is needed to identify the source of infection.
2. Hypotension: The patient requires higher levels of pressor support despite weaning of sedation and PEEP. This may be due to worsening liver failure with splanchnic vasodilation and third spacing leading to decreased effective circulating volume, or sepsis. No laboratory evidence of adrenal insufficiency.
3. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for restrictive physiology, mental status changes, and concern for volume overload. The patient's atelectasis has improved,

He also has fulminant hepatic failure, likely secondary to severe veno-occlusive disease (VOD) following the SCT. The patient's condition is further complicated by hypotension, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, hyperglycemia, and encephalopathy.

The patient's current medications include calcium gluconate, fentanyl, norepinephrine, propofol, potassium chloride, pantoprazole, ranitidine, and acyclovir. The patient's labs show elevated liver enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.

The patient's medical team is concerned about several potential medical complications. These include hypotension, hypoxic respiratory failure, ileus, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, hyperglycemia, and fulminant hepatic failure. The team is also monitoring for complications related to the patient's recent SCT, such as VOD and coagulopathy.

   with rising leukocytosis despite broa
   1) Leukocytosis: WBC count bumped from 24 to 29 despite vanc/cefepime
   coverage. Sputum gram stain w/ GPRs and GPCs. Possible sources include
   C diff (given long-term hospitalization, ileus, possible feculent
   aspiration), SBP, line infection, pancreatitis. Will hold on diagnostic
   para, given bleeding risk, plus pt is already on GNR coverage. Fever
   curve difficult to interpret, given CVVHD. No evidence of biliary
   infection on RUQ US. No evidence of PNA on CXR. ID following.

   2) Hypotension: Pt requiring higher levels of pressor support despite
   weaning of sedation and PEEP. Most likely explanation is worsening
   liver failure with splanchnic vasodilation and third spacing leading to
   decreased effective circulating volume. Also possible that patient is
   septic, given metabolic acidosis and increased white count on
   antibiotics. No laboratory evidence of adrenal insufficiency.

   3) Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**] for worsening hypoxia
   and respiratory fatigue. Pt remains intubated for a) restrictive
   physiology [**3-4**] ascites, b) mental status changes [**3-4**] encephalopathy, c)
   concern for volume overload. Pt switched from AC to CPAP+PSV on [**4-16**].
   Atelctasis and lung volumes improving (per [**2155-4-17**] CXR) w/o
   paracentesis. Pt able to maintain PaO2>90 on PEEP 12.
   -Decrease PEEP to 10 today

   -Daily CXR
   4) Ileus: Resolving. +Stool with suppository overnight. Low stool
   output, high residuals, ?stool on suctioning, reduced bowel sounds all
   concerning for ileus in the setting of critical illness and ascites.
   Other possible explanations include C diff infection w/ toxic
   megacolon, or pancreatitis. KUB negative for obstruction.

    (c.) Ascites: Stable. Bladder pressures ~20mmHg. Have been holding
