   Assessment and Plan
   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 24 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease, on dofibritide day 20/21 with ICU course complicated by
   persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal
   failure requiring [**Last Name (un) **], and respiratory failure requiring ventilator
   support.
   #) Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   likely combination of a) intravascular volume depletion [**3-4**] decreased
   effective circulating volume and splanchinic vasodilation from liver
   failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for sepsis thoguh cultures
   negative to date and has been on broad spectrum antibiotics for a long
   time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to meropenem yesterday.  Given
   difference on opinion regarding antifungal treatement, maintained
   micafungin treatment.
   -IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of MAP>65,
   SBP>85
   -Continue norepinephrine; wean as tolerated
   -Start vasopressin if pt reaches max doses of norepinephrine, though
   2nd pressor would mean DQ from defibrotide trial
   -Continue abx and infectious work-up (below)
   -Hold steroids, given no clear indication at present
   #) Leukocytosis: WBC down to 11 today. Unclear etiology, given pt is
   s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) 350**]/Micafungin, with
   negative cultures to date. No PMNs on yesterdays para.
   -f/u cultures: catheter tip, blood, peritoneal fluid
   -Continue Vanc/[**Last Name (un) 350**]/Micafungin, dosed for [**Last Name (un) **]
   #) Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for mental
   status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy, also restrictive
   physiology [**3-4**] intra-abdominal pressure, anasarca.
   -Plan for tracheostomy but hold off on consult, pending results of
   liver bx
   - maintain current vent settings
   - AM CXR
   #) Hepatic Failure: Etiology is most likely VOD [**3-4**] SCT. Reversal of
   flow in main portal vein demonstrated on US and MRI. Possible
   underlying cirrhosis [**3-4**] EtOH history. Had para [**4-20**], again [**4-25**] with
   3L off, bladder pressure after was 14.
   Per email communication with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 12202**] (PI on defibrotide
   study), median duration of defibrotide therapy for VOD is 19 d; 21-d
   course recommended d/t concern for relapse if tx held earlier; look for
   CR at 21-d (CR defined in [**2147**] [**Company 4816**] study as evidence of improvement in
   VOD-related symptoms and concurrent MOF, and a concomitant or
   subsequent decrease in bilirubin to less than 2 mg/dL), then
   re-evaluate. Appreciate hepatology input.
   -f/u liver biopsy results
   -Continue 21-day course of defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for
   VOD (targets for admin: Plt>30, Hct>30, INR<1.5, Fibrinogen>150), but
   hold 2 doses before and 2 doses after liver bx
   -Urusodiol via OGT
   -Q6H labs to monitor defibrotide parameters (Hct, INR)
   -Continue bladder pressure measurements
   - hepatology recs
   #) Anasarca: Patient + 21L LOS.  This is likely contributing to his
   respiratory compromise.  We have been maintaining his blood pressure
   with boluses and levophed.  If we stop the dofibritide, and the goals
   of care remain curative/supportive, we could consider supporting his
   pressure with increased pressors and remove fluid with CVVH
   #) Acidemia: Pt
s ABG this AM reflects concurrent gap and non-gap
   metabolic acidosis [**3-4**] renal failure, and respiratory acidosis,
   discussed above.
   -[**Month/Day (2) **] adjustments, per renal
   -Adjust vent settings to increase pressure support, as above
   #) Oliguric ARF: Pt started on [**Month/Day (2) **] [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function. Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts). Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome. Pt remains extremely volume overloaded
   but cannot run negative on [**Month/Day (2) **] [**3-4**] hypotension. Pt has persistent
   metabolic acidosis, as above. Creatinine down-trending slowly, 2.4
   today from peak of 3.4 on [**4-14**]. Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP. Renal is following.
   -Continue [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 77**] renal recs
   -Trend pH, calcium, lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   -Dose meds for [**First Name3 (LF) **]
   #) Altered Mental Status: Stable. Pt able to follow only mouth
   commands. Alteration likely [**3-4**] toxic/metabolic encephalopathy [**3-4**]
   liver failure and uremia, as well as sedation.
   -Lactulose QID; hold on PR, given difficulty turning patient
   -Repeat Spontaneous Awakening Trial tonight
   #) Ileus: No stool output or bowel sounds for past 4-5 days, also high
   output from OG tube, likely functional ileus, given pt is critically
   ill and on high doses of opioids. No obstruction on CT read.
   -Continue Reglan at 15mg in TPN
   -Aggressive bowel regimen
   -Wean sedation as tolerated
   #) Goals of care.  BMT social work following.  Dependent on completion
   of dofibritide, liver bx results, may readdress goals of care.
   #) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 23. BMT and Social
   Work are following.
   -Continue acyclovir ppx
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   TPN w/ Lipids - [**2155-4-25**] 05:58 PM 80 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin in TPN

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and is now in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient's current condition includes hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, anasarca, acidemia, oliguric acute renal failure, altered mental status, ileus, and functional bowel obstruction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may be due to intravascular volume depletion and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and the pressor requirement has been reduced overnight. IV fluid boluses will be given as needed to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg and systemic blood pressure (SBP) above 85 mmHg.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, but the etiology is unclear. No abscess is present on the CT scan, and the patient is on appropriate antibiotics with negative cultures. Further monitoring and evaluation are needed.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated due to mental status changes, sedation, encephalopathy, and restrictive physiology. Tracheostomy planning is

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto stem cell transplant (SCT) on day 23. He was transferred to the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure and occlusive disease. The patient's current condition is complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring dialysis, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension likely due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is concern for sepsis, but cultures remain negative. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and the pressor requirement has been reduced overnight.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, but the etiology is unclear. He has undergone recent line changes, and cultures remain negative. The patient is on vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and micafungin.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for mental status changes, sedation, and restrictive lung physiology. He is on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and has a reduced lung volume with new retrocardiac atelectasis on chest X-ray. The ABG indicates respiratory acidosis, and there are plans to increase the PSV and P

   disease, on dofibritide day 20/21 with ICU course complicated by
   persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal
   failure requiring [**Last Name (un) **], and respiratory failure requiring ventilator
   support.
   #) Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   likely combination of a) intravascular volume depletion [**3-4**] decreased
   effective circulating volume and splanchinic vasodilation from liver
   failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for sepsis thoguh cultures
   negative to date and has been on broad spectrum antibiotics for a long
   time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to meropenem yesterday.  Given
   difference on opinion regarding antifungal treatement, maintained
   micafungin treatment.
   -IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of MAP>65,
   SBP>85
   -Continue norepinephrine; wean as tolerated
   -Start vasopressin if pt reaches max doses of norepinephrine, though
   2nd pressor would mean DQ from defibrotide trial
   -Continue abx and infectious work-up (below)
   -Hold steroids, given no clear indication at present
   #) Leukocytosis: WBC down to 11 today. Unclear etiology, given pt is
   s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) 350**]/Micafungin, with
   negative cultures to date. No PMNs on yesterdays para.
   -f/u cultures: catheter tip, blood, peritoneal fluid

   #) Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for mental

   -Plan for tracheostomy but hold off on consult, pending results of
   liver bx
   - maintain current vent settings
   - AM CXR
   #) Hepatic Failure: Etiology is most likely VOD [**3-4**] SCT. Reversal of
   flow in main portal vein demonstrated on US and MRI. Possible
   underlying cirrhosis [**3-4**] EtOH history. Had para [**4-20**], again [**4-25**] with
   3L off, bladder pressure after was 14.
   Per email communication with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 12202**] (PI on defibrotide
   study), median duration of defibrotide therapy for VOD is 19 d; 21-d
   course recommended d/t concern for relapse if tx held earlier; look for
   CR at 21-d (CR defined in [**2147**] [**Company 4816**] study as evidence of improvement in
   VOD-related symptoms and concurrent MOF, and a concomitant or
   subsequent decrease in bilirubin to less than 2 mg/dL), then
   re-evaluate. Appreciate hepatology input.
   -f/u liver biopsy results
   -Continue 21-day course of defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for

s ABG this AM reflects concurrent gap and non-gap

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT and is now experiencing fulminant hepatic failure. The patient has been on dofibritide for 20 days and is in the ICU with a complicated course characterized by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CRRT, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

Medical Complications:
1) Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sepsis is also a concern, despite negative cultures. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and the pressor requirement has reduced overnight. The goal is to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 65 and systemic blood pressure (SBP) > 85.

2) Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has decreased to 11 today. The cause of leukocytosis is unclear, as there are no abscesses, and the patient is on appropriate antibiotics with negative cultures. Further investigation is needed, including follow-up cultures, catheter tip cultures, and blood cultures.

3) Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for mental status changes, sedation, encephalopathy, and restrictive physiology due to intra-abdominal pressure and anasarca.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 98.2 kg individual currently weighing 114.7 kg, with a height not mentioned. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate (HR) ranging from 118 to 138 beats per minute, blood pressure (BP) ranging from 66/47 to 163/87 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) set at 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) at 100%. The patient's rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient has received multiple antibiotics, including amphotericin, vancomycin, meropenem, cefepime, and flagyl. These antibiotics have been adjusted based on culture results. The patient's blood cultures are ongoing.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) ranging from 11.7 to 14.8 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hct) ranging from 30.4 to 35.9%, platelet count (Plt) ranging from 70 to 81 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) ranging from 2.3 to 2.4 mg/dL, total CO2 (TCO2) ranging from 23 to 25 mEq/L, and glucose levels ranging from 99 to 139 mg/dL. Other lab results indicate elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase), elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and abnormal electrolyte levels (Na+, K+, Cl-, HCO3-).

The patient's imaging shows a chest X-ray with persistently low lung volumes, with no significant interval change. 

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing ICU care, nutrition via total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with lipids, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory status leading to further hypoxia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, indicating possible liver dysfunction. Additionally, the patient's elevated lactate levels may suggest poor tissue perfusion or sepsis. The patient's renal function is impaired, as indicated by the elevated creatinine levels. These complications should be closely monitored and managed accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   56yM with refractory follicular lymphoma, day 25 s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease, on dofibritide day 21/21 with ICU course complicated by
   persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal
   failure requiring [**Last Name (un) **], and respiratory failure requiring ventilator
   support.  Now with labs this morning suggestive of worsening liver
   function.
   #) Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   likely combination of a) intravascular volume depletion [**3-4**] decreased
   effective circulating volume and splanchinic vasodilation from liver
   failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for sepsis thoguh cultures
   negative to date and has been on broad spectrum antibiotics for a long
   time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to meropenem [**4-25**].  Given
   difference on opinion regarding antifungal treatement, maintained
   micafungin treatment. Per BMT yesterday will hold off on amphotericin
   tx for possibility of occult fungal infection since pt seemed somewhat
   mildly improved (requiring less pressure support)- on
   vanc/mica/meropenem.  PO vancomycin discontinued yesterday given cdiff
   negative lab results.
   - Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of
   MAP>65, SBP>85
   -Wean pressors as tolerated
   -Start vasopressin if pt reaches max doses of norepinephrine, though
   2nd pressor would mean DQ from defibrotide trial
   -Continue abx and infectious work-up (below)
   -Hold steroids, given no clear indication at present
   #) Leukocytosis: WBC slightly increased at 14.8 today. Unclear
   etiology, given pt is s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on
   Vanc/[**Last Name (un) 350**]/Micafungin, with negative cultures to date. No PMNs on [**4-25**]
   paracentesis.
   -f/u cultures
   -Continue Vanc/[**Last Name (un) 350**]/Micafungin, dosed for [**Last Name (un) **]
   #) Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for mental
   status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy, also restrictive
   physiology [**3-4**] intra-abdominal pressure, anasarca.
   -Plan for tracheostomy but hold off on consult, pending results of
   liver bx
   - maintain current vent settings
   - AM CXR
   #) Hepatic Failure: Etiology is most likely VOD [**3-4**] SCT. Reversal of
   flow in main portal vein demonstrated on US and MRI. Possible
   underlying cirrhosis [**3-4**] EtOH history. Had para [**4-20**], again [**4-25**] with
   3L off, bladder pressure after was 14.
   Per email communication with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 12202**] (PI on defibrotide
   study), median duration of defibrotide therapy for VOD is 19 d; 21-d
   course recommended d/t concern for relapse if tx held earlier; look for
   CR at 21-d (CR defined in [**2147**] [**Company 4816**] study as evidence of improvement in
   VOD-related symptoms and concurrent MOF, and a concomitant or
   subsequent decrease in bilirubin to less than 2 mg/dL), then
   re-evaluate. Appreciate hepatology input.  AST and Tbili increased
   today.
   -f/u liver biopsy results
   -Continue 21-day course of defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for
   VOD (targets for admin: Plt>30, Hct>30, INR<1.5, Fibrinogen>150), but
   hold 2 doses before and 2 doses after liver bx
   -Urusodiol via OGT
   -Q6H labs to monitor defibrotide parameters (Hct, INR)
   -Continue bladder pressure measurements
   - hepatology recs
   #) Anasarca: Patient + 19L LOS.  This is likely contributing to his
   respiratory compromise.  We have been maintaining his blood pressure
   with boluses and levophed.  If we stop the dofibritide, and the goals
   of care remain curative/supportive, we could consider supporting his
   pressure with increased pressors and remove fluid with CVVH
   #) Oliguric ARF: Pt started on [**Company **] [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function. Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts). Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome. Pt remains extremely volume overloaded
   but cannot run negative on [**Month/Day (2) **] [**3-4**] hypotension. Pt has persistent
   metabolic acidosis, as above. Creatinine down-trending slowly, 2.4
   today from peak of 3.4 on [**4-14**]. Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP. Renal is following.
   -Continue [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 77**] renal recs
   -Trend pH, calcium, lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   -Dose meds for [**First Name3 (LF) **]
   #) Altered Mental Status: Stable. Pt able to follow only mouth
   commands. Alteration likely [**3-4**] toxic/metabolic encephalopathy [**3-4**]
   liver failure and uremia, as well as sedation.
   -Lactulose QID; hold on PR, given difficulty turning patient
   -Repeat Spontaneous Awakening Trials daily
   #) Ileus: No stool output or bowel sounds for past 4-5 days, also high
   output from OG tube, likely functional ileus, given pt is critically
   ill and on high doses of opioids. No obstruction on CT read.
   -Continue Reglan at 15mg in TPN
   -Aggressive bowel regimen
   -Wean sedation as tolerated
   #) Goals of care.  BMT social work following.  Dependent on completion
   of dofibritide, liver bx results, may readdress goals of care; family
   would like to do this Monday, [**4-28**]. They are very anxious about biopsy
   results.
   #) Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 23. BMT and Social
   Work are following.
   -Continue acyclovir ppx
   ICU Care

   Glycemic Control:  Insulin in TPN

   Mouth care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been admitted to the ICU. He underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and is now experiencing multiple complications. The patient has fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD), which is a known complication of SCT. He also has persistent hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, and respiratory failure. The patient's liver function tests are worsening, indicating ongoing liver dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly increased at 14.8. The cause of leukocytosis is unclear, considering the patient has had line changes without evidence of abscess, is on appropriate antibiotics, and has negative cultures.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for mental status changes, sedation, restrictive physiology, and anasarca. A plan for tracheostomy has been made, pending results of the liver biopsy.

4. Hepatic Failure: The etiology of the patient's hep

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone a BEAM auto SCT and is now in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient's current condition includes hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, hepatic failure, anasarca, and altered mental status. 

The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchnic vasodilation from liver failure. The etiology of the leukocytosis is unclear, as the patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has negative cultures. The respiratory failure is a result of mental status changes, sedation, and restrictive physiology with intra-abdominal pressure and anasarca. Hepatic failure is likely due to VOD post-SCT, with evidence of reversal of flow in the main portal vein on US and MRI. Anasarca is contributing to the patient's respiratory compromise. Oliguric acute renal failure is most likely ischemic ATN, with an initial insult of hypotension and possible hepatorenal syndrome. The altered mental status is likely due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy, liver failure, uremia, and sedation.

Based on the patient's condition and the attending physician's assessment, the plan of care includes continuing defibrotide for VOD, supporting blood pressure with boluses and vasopressors, f/u liver biopsy

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) on day 23. He was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, on day 21 of defibrotide therapy. The ICU course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. Pressors and IV fluid boluses will be given as needed to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) >85 mmHg. Vasopressin may be considered if the patient reaches the maximum doses of norepinephrine.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly increased at 16.2. The etiology is unclear, given that the patient has had line changes without abscess on CT, is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and has negative cultures. cultures will be followed, and the current antibiotics will be continued.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for mental status changes, sedation, restrictive physiology, and anasarca. A plan for tracheostomy has been made, but it will be held off pending the results of the liver biopsy. Current vent settings will be maintained, and an AM chest X-ray will be done.

4. Hepatic Failure: The etiology of hepatic failure is most likely VOD post-SCT. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on ultrasound and MRI. Possible underlying cirrhosis may also contribute. The patient is on a 21-day course of defibrotide (560 mg IV Q6H) per protocol for VOD. Liver biopsy results will determine the course of treatment.

5. Anasarca: The patient has significant edema and fluid overload, contributing to respiratory compromise. If the goals of care remain curative/supportive, consideration can be given to supporting his pressure with increased pressors and removing fluid with CVVH.

6. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: The patient has ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with muddy brown casts, likely due to hypotension. He is oliguric with no indication of improved renal function. Renal function will be monitored, and the current renal recommendations will be followed.

7. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is stable but altered, likely due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy, liver

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an allogeneic stem cell transplant (SCT) 25 days ago. He is currently admitted to the ICU with multiple complications including fulminant hepatic failure, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVH), and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension, which is likely due to intravascular volume depletion and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, despite negative cultures. The patient's leukocytosis is unclear in etiology, and he has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics. His respiratory failure is attributed to mental status changes, sedation, and restrictive physiology. The patient's hepatic failure is likely due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) secondary to the SCT, as evidenced by reversal of flow in the main portal vein on ultrasound and MRI. Anasarca is contributing to his respiratory compromise, and he has oliguric acute renal failure with a history of hypotension and possible hepatorenal syndrome. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy, liver failure, uremia, and sedation. He also has ileus, which is functional given his critical illness and opioid use. The patient's goals

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto stem cell transplantation on day 23. He was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, on day 25. He has been on defibrotide therapy since day 21, and his ICU course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate of 133 beats per minute, blood pressure of 121/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 100%, and a temperature of 36.7 degrees Celsius. The patient is sedated and paralyzed, with no bowel sounds present. His abdomen is distended with ascites. He has edema in both lower extremities. The patient's mental status is altered, and he is unable to follow commands.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.2 thousand/mm3, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 62 thousand/mm3, elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST), and hyponatremia with a sodium level of 101 mEq/L.

The patient's plan of care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who is currently in the ICU. He has been transferred from another hospital with fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) post-stem cell transplantation. The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The family has decided against further escalations of care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Hepatic Failure: The patient has confirmed VOD post-stem cell transplantation. His liver enzymes and bilirubin levels are increasing but stable. He is currently on defibrotide therapy, which needs to be continued with close monitoring of liver function tests (LFTs), platelet count, hematocrit (Hct), international normalized ratio (INR), and fibrinogen levels.
2) Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure remains low, and he requires vasopressor support. The etiology of hypotension is likely a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and sedation. There is also concern for sepsis, despite negative cultures.
3) Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated. The cause of leukocytosis is unclear, given recent line changes

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been admitted to the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure and is currently on defibrotide therapy for VOD post-splenectomy. The patient's condition is complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CRRT, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate of 132 bpm, blood pressure of 100/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on ventilator support. The patient's temperature is within normal range at 36.7°C (98°F).

Physical examination reveals tachycardia, right lower extremity edema, left lower extremity edema, warm skin, jaundice, and decreased movement with unresponsive mental status.

Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST: 32/58), increased total bilirubin (24 mg/dL), low albumin (2.6 g/dL), and elevated lactate acid (1.3 mmol/L). Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient's recent course has been complicated by various medical issues including hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, anasarca, and oliguric acute renal failure. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to toxic/metabolic

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant (BMT) unit to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient's current condition is complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 126 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 94/77 mmHg to 115/77 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on the ventilator. The patient's physical examination findings include an altered mental status, no peripheral pulses, and no skin abnormalities.

The patient is currently on day 24 of defibrotide therapy and is in the ICU with multiple complications.

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided are:

1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has been diagnosed with VOD (veno-occlusive disease) post-transplant, which is confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on US and MRI. The patient is continuing defibrotide therapy for an indefinite period as recommended by Dr. [First Name (STitle) 2355]. It is important to monitor liver enzymes, including bilirubin, and follow hepatology recommendations.

2. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension, which may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures remain negative. Pressors, IV fluid boluses, and vasopressin may be required to maintain MAP >65 and SBP >85.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who has undergone BEAM Auto SCT and is now in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient's current condition includes hepatic failure due to VOD post-SCT, hypotension, leukocytosis, respiratory failure requiring ventilator support, anasarca, oliguric acute renal failure, altered mental status, ileus, and follicular lymphoma.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has hepatic failure secondary to VOD post-SCT. Continued monitoring of liver enzymes and bilirubin levels is recommended. Defibrotide therapy should be continued as per protocol to manage VOD.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Pressor requirements should be closely monitored and adjusted accordingly. IV fluid boluses may be given as needed to maintain MAP>65 and SBP>85.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is increasing despite negative cultures and appropriate antibiotic coverage. Further investigation is needed to determine the etiology of leukocytosis.

4. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to mental status changes, sedation, encephalopathy, restrictive physiology, and anasarca. Current ventilator settings

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT). He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient's conditions include hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) post-SCT, hypotension, altered mental status, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, ileus, and malignancy (lymphoma).

The patient's current treatment plan includes:
- Continuing defibrotide for VOD management
- Monitoring liver enzymes and bilirubin levels
- Maintaining bladder pressure measurements
- Following hepatology recommendations
- Managing hypotension with pressors and IV fluid boluses
- Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics and infectious work-up
- Holding steroids
- Continuing CVVHD with close monitoring of blood pressure
- Investigating the cause of leukocytosis
- Maintaining current ventilator settings
- Assessing the corneal lesion
- Addressing altered mental status with sedation management and lactulose
- Addressing ileus with medication adjustments and trial lactulose enema

The patient's goals of care are being discussed with the BMT social work team, and the patient has a DNR status with no major escalations in care.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent autologous bone marrow transplant (BMT) and subsequently developed fulminant hepatic failure. The patient's ICU course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous venovenous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has confirmed veno-occlusive disease (VOD) after stem cell transplantation. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The patient is being treated with defibrotide, which will be continued indefinitely until liver enzymes and bilirubin levels improve.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. The etiology is still under investigation, and the patient's pressor requirements have reduced overnight.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count continues to increase, but the cause is unclear. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and cultures have been negative to date. No abscess was detected on computed tomography (CT) scan, and there are no polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent a BEAM Auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure. The patient's ICU course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient remains critically ill with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has been diagnosed with fulminant hepatic failure, confirmed by biopsy results. This condition can lead to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and hepatorenal syndrome.
2. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and possibly sepsis.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient has an increasing white blood cell count despite being on broad-spectrum antibiotics and having negative cultures. The cause of this leukocytosis is unclear and needs further investigation.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient requires ventilator support due to respiratory failure. The underlying causes include airway protection due to mental status changes, restrictive physiology, anasarca, and possibly opioid-induced respiratory depression.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) with muddy

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous bone marrow transplant (BMT) and is now in the ICU. He has been diagnosed with multiple medical complications, including hepatic failure, hypotension, altered mental status, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and ascites. The patient's current condition is complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The family has decided against further escalations of care, and the patient has a DNR status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient is experiencing fulminant hepatic failure, which can lead to liver dysfunction and failure of other organs. This condition requires careful monitoring and management of liver function tests and bilirubin levels.

2. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension, which may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and sepsis. Pressor support is required to maintain adequate blood pressure.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy, liver failure, uremia, and sedation. Close monitoring of neurological status and regular spontaneous awakening trials are recommended.

4. Respiratory Failure:

The patient's current conditions include hepatic failure (fulminant [**Last Name (un)**]-occlusive disease), hypotension (not shock), alteration in nutrition, respiratory failure (acute), renal failure (acute), hepatic encephalopathy, lymphoma (cancer, malignant neoplasm, lymphoid), transplant (bone marrow, BMT), liver function abnormalities, among others.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 8 cmH2O. The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 21.7 K/uL, elevated liver enzymes, and renal dysfunction.

The patient's current medications include norepinephrine, calcium gluconate (CRRT), KCl (CRRT), pantoprazole, dextrose, midazolam, fentanyl, and others. The patient is also receiving TPN with lipids and has multiple IV lines, including an arterial line.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and is now in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient's current medical issues include hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD), hypotension, leukocytosis, respiratory failure, anasarca, oliguric acute renal failure, corneal lesion, altered mental status, ileus, and a history of cancer (lymphoma).

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver function is severely impaired, which can lead to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and other systemic complications.

2. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension can result in organ perfusion failure and shock. It may require continuous monitoring and management of blood pressure with appropriate medications and fluid resuscitation.

3. Leukocytosis: The increase in white blood cell count may indicate an ongoing infection or inflammation. It is important to monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.

4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and ventilator settings adjusted as necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

5. Anasarca: The patient's generalized edema can contribute to respiratory compromise and increase the risk of infections. Fluid management

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto stem cell transplant and is now experiencing multiple medical complications in the ICU. 

The patient has been diagnosed with hepatic failure due to VOD (veno-occlusive disease) confirmed by biopsy results. The reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on US and MRI. The patient is currently on defibrotide therapy, which will be continued indefinitely until there is improvement in VOD-related symptoms and a decrease in bilirubin levels.

The patient also has hypotension, which is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. The patient is on multiple pressors to maintain blood pressure above 65 mmHg and has been weaned off sedation.

The patient has leukocytosis with a WBC count of 21.7, which is unclear in etiology despite negative cultures and line changes. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungals.

The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation support due to mental status changes, encephalopathy, and anasarca. The patient's fluid overload has been managed through CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) without any drop in blood pressure or increased pressor requirement.

Additionally, the patient has acute renal failure, most likely ischemic ATN (acute tubular necrosis), with muddy brown casts seen in urine sediment. The initial insult was hypotension, possibly hepatorenal syndrome or increased intra-abdominal pressure. The patient remains extremely volume overloaded with a creatinine level of 2.2.

The patient also has a corneal lesion in the right eye, which needs further evaluation to determine the cause. The patient has ileus, likely functional due to critical illness and opioid use, but responded well to lactulose enema.

The patient's goals of care are DNR (do not resuscitate) with no major escalations, and defibrotide will be continued indefinitely.

The patient's medical history includes follicular lymphoma, BEAM auto stem cell transplant, and subsequent complications in the ICU.

Based on the provided information, the patient has a complex medical history with multiple acute and chronic conditions. The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT (bone marrow transplant) and is now experiencing complications in the ICU.

The patient's current medical conditions include:
1. Hepatic failure with VOD (veno-occlusive disease), confirmed by biopsy results and reversal of flow in the main portal vein.
2. Hypotension, possibly due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure.
3. Leukocytosis with an unclear etiology despite negative cultures and no abscess on CT.
4. Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation for airway protection due to mental status changes, sedation, encephalopathy, restrictive physiology, and anasarca.
5. Oliguric acute renal failure (ARF) with ischemic ATN (acute tubular necrosis) and possible hepatorenal syndrome or increased intra-abdominal pressure as contributing factors.
6. Corneal lesion in the right eye with an unknown etiology.
7. Altered mental status with toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia.
8. Ileus with no stool output or bowel sounds, likely functional due to critical illness and high doses of opioids.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Progressive liver failure

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous bone marrow transplant (Auto SCT) and is now in the ICU due to various complications. The patient has several medical conditions and potential medical complications that need to be addressed:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is stable but does not make purposeful movements or respond to commands when off sedation. Initially thought to be toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. The plan is to continue lactulose, repeat spontaneous awakening trials daily, keep sedation low, and rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus with an EEG.

2. Hepatic Failure: The patient has VOD (veno-occlusive disease) post-SCT, confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein is demonstrated on US and MRI. The patient had para-prothrombin time (PT) with a bladder pressure of 14 after stopping defibrotide. Dr. recommends continuing defibrotide for an indefinite time period at this time. The median duration of defibrotide therapy for VOD is 19 days, and a 21-day course is recommended due to concern for relapse if treatment is held earlier. Look for CR (complete response) at 21 days. Appreciate hepatology input.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto SCT and is currently in the ICU. The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient's family has decided against further escalations of care.

Assessment and plan:
1) Altered Mental Status: The patient has been sedated due to encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. Lactulose has been started to manage hepatic encephalopathy. EEG is being monitored to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus. An MRI has been ordered to evaluate for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), and no mass effects were noted.
2) Hepatic Failure: The patient has VOD (veno-occlusive disease) post SCT, confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on US and MRI. Defibrotide therapy will be continued indefinitely at this time. Hepatology input is appreciated, and follow-up liver enzymes and bilirubin levels will be monitored.
3) Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sepsis is also a concern, although cultures have been negative to date

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT).
- He was transferred from the bone marrow transplant (BMT) unit with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease.
- The patient is currently on day 24 of defibrotide therapy.
- He has been in the ICU with a complicated course, including persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.
- The patient's family held a meeting to decide against further escalations of care.
- The patient's mental status is altered but stable. There are concerns of toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia.
- The patient has hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
- The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative.
- The patient has leukocytosis of unknown etiology, with no abscess per CT, on vancomycin intraven

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent auto stem cell transplant (SCT) and was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant (BMT) unit. He presented with fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) confirmed by biopsy, reversal of flow in the main portal vein on ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and a history of sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS).

The patient's current condition is as follows:
1. Altered Mental Status: The patient is unresponsive and does not make purposeful movements or respond to commands. Initially, it was thought to be toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. Lactulose has been continued, spontaneous awakening trials are done daily, sedation is kept low, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) has ruled out nonconvulsive status epilepticus.
2. Hepatic Failure: The patient has confirmed VOD/SOS post-SCT. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on US and MRI. The patient received 25 days of defibrotide, which was discontinued on [3-4]. Hepatology input has been appreciated, and the patient's liver enzymes are stable with elevated but stable alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos). Ursodiol has been initiated via oral gastrointestinal tube (OGT), and

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation and was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit. He presented with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD (veno-occlusive disease) secondary to stem cell transplantation. The patient's ICU course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered Mental Status: The patient is currently experiencing altered mental status, which may be attributed to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. It is important to continue lactulose, perform spontaneous awakening trials daily, keep sedation low, and rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus through an EEG.

2. Hepatic Failure: The patient has confirmed VOD secondary to stem cell transplantation. There is a reversal of flow in the main portal vein demonstrated on ultrasound and MRI. The patient has received defibrotide, which has been discontinued due to the development of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Ursodiol has been initiated via oral gastrointestinal tube.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been transferred from the BMT unit with fulminant hepatic failure due to [**Hospital 11923**]-occlusive disease. He is on day 24 of defibrotide therapy and has been in the ICU with a complicated course including persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The family has decided against further escalations of care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered Mental Status: The patient does not seem to make purposeful movements or respond to commands when off sedation. Initially thought to be toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. EEG ruled out nonconvulsive status epilepticus; consistent with encephalopathy. An MRI showed no mass effects.

2. Hepatic Failure: The patient has VOD (veno-occlusive disease) post stem cell transplantation, confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on US and MRI. There was also a paracentesis performed.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative. Broad

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation. He was transferred from the BMT unit with fulminant hepatic failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient has several medical complications that need to be addressed.

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, which is stable. He does not respond to commands or make purposeful movements when off sedation. This could be due to toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. Further evaluation with EEG and MRI should be considered to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

2. Hepatic Failure: The patient has VOD (veno-occlusive disease) secondary to stem cell transplantation. This is confirmed by biopsy results and demonstrated by reversal of flow in the main portal vein on US and MRI. The patient has had two episodes of variceal bleeding, and defibrotide was continued indefinitely. The liver enzymes are stable with elevated but stable alkaline phosphatase. Ursodiol via OGT is recommended, and hepatology input is appreciated.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures are negative. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered, and the patient's pressor requirements

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent auto stem cell transplantation (SCT). He is currently in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient's condition is summarized as follows:

- The patient has been diagnosed with fulminant hepatic failure secondary to VOD (veno-occlusive disease) of the liver after stem cell transplantation.
- He also has respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.
- The patient is experiencing persistent hypotension, which may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and potential sepsis.
- He has leukocytosis with a WBC count of 22.0, and the etiology is unclear despite negative cultures.
- The patient has acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD).
- He has an ileus that has now resolved with significant bowel movements on lactulose.
- The patient has corneal lesions in his right eye, which require further evaluation.
- He has been diagnosed with follicular lymphoma and is post BEAM auto SCT, day 24.
- The patient's current medications include norepinephrine, calcium gluconate (CRRT), potassium chloride (CRRT), pantoprazole (Protonix), midazolam (Versed), and various other medications.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has been admitted to the ICU. He has a history of undergoing a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and is currently experiencing multiple medical complications.

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient has stable altered mental status with no purposeful movements or response to commands. Initial thoughts suggest toxic/metabolic encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia. An EEG has been ordered to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

2. Hepatic Failure: The patient is diagnosed with VOD (veno-occlusive disease) secondary to stem cell transplantation (SCT), confirmed by biopsy results. Reversal of flow in the main portal vein was demonstrated on ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The patient received 25 days of defibrotide, which was discontinued on [**3-4**]. A hepatology consult is appreciated.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is believed to be caused by a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sedation may also be a contributing factor. There is concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who has been transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit. He is currently in the ICU with multiple complications including fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease post stem cell transplant, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has developed hepatic failure secondary to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) post stem cell transplant. This condition is confirmed by biopsy results and reversal of flow in the main portal vein on ultrasound and MRI. The patient received defibrotide for an indefinite period, but it was discontinued due to the development of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). There are concerns regarding ongoing hepatology issues and the need for further evaluation and management.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be attributed to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date. The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for a prolonged duration. Pressors have been used to maintain adequate blood pressure, and CVVH will be continued while closely monitoring the patient's blood pressure.

3. Leukocyt

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who was transferred from a bone marrow transplant (BMT) unit. He has a history of fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide. The patient also experienced subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and persistent hypotension. He has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has had multiple line changes without any abscess seen on CT scan. The patient's current condition includes hepatic failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, respiratory failure requiring ventilator support, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hepatic Failure: The patient has confirmed VOD (veno-occlusive disease) post stem cell transplant (SCT), with elevated liver enzymes and reversal of flow in the main portal vein demonstrated on US and MRI. The patient is being treated with defibrotide, which may need to be continued indefinitely.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count continues to increase, despite negative

3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count continues to increase, but the cause is unclear. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and has negative cultures.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone BEAM auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The patient's course was further complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient has continued to improve in terms of mental status and respiratory stability.

The patient's current medical complications include respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 37.1°C (98.8°F)
- Heart rate: 119 bpm (with a normal range of 111-129 bpm)
- Blood pressure: 93/60 mmHg (with a normal range of 72-120/53-86 mmHg)
- Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute (with a normal range of 20-26 breaths per minute)
- Oxygen saturation: 100% on ventilator support

The patient's laboratory results show:
- White blood cell count: 27.6 K/uL (with a normal range of 4.5-11 K/uL)
- Hemoglobin: 12.2 g/dL (with a normal range of 13.5-17.5 g/dL)
- Platelet count: 126 K/uL (with a normal range of 150-450 K/uL)
- Creatinine: 2

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease. The course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient has continued to improve in terms of mental status and respiratory stability.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes, sedation, and encephalopathy. There is also restrictive physiology with intra-abdominal pressure and anasarca. The patient's clinical status has improved, but he is still debilitated with a NIF of -20. Extubation will be held until NIF improves, and repeat SBTs will be done daily.

2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirement has reduced overnight. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sedation is also a concern. The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for a long time, and there is concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative. Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent an autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) followed by a BEAM regimen. He was transferred from the bone marrow transplant (BMT) unit due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by sinusoidal obstructive syndrome (VOD) post-SCT, which led to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. 

The patient's current condition includes refractory respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, refractory hypotension, leukocytosis with negative cultures, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), hepatic failure with persistent hyperbilirubinemia, and anasarca. The patient's mental status has improved, but he remains sedated and does not have purposeful movements or respond to commands. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, hepatic failure, anasarca, and altered mental status. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and the need for continued ventilatory support may be evaluated. The hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as possible sepsis. Leukocytosis could be due to a stress response or other causes that need further investigation. Acute renal failure requires ongoing management with CRRT, and hepatic failure may

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who has undergone BEAM auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and transferred from the bone marrow transplant (BMT) unit. The patient's clinical course has been complicated by fulminant hepatic failure due to sinusoidal obstructive syndrome (SOS), acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), septic shock, and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His respiratory system compliance has improved, and he is tolerating spontaneous breathing trials (SBT). There is a plan to continue weaning him off the ventilator.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is stable, and the vasopressor requirements have reduced. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be intravascular volume depletion and splanchinic vasodilation due to liver failure. There is a plan to maintain an even fluid balance and wean off the vasopressors.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has improved significantly. An electroencephalogram (EEG) has ruled out nonconvulsive status epilepticus. There is a plan to continue repeating spontaneous awakening trials (SAT) daily and hold sedation medications.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient had veno-occlusive disease (VOD)

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient remains critically ill but has shown overall improvement in his condition.

The patient's respiratory status remains a concern, as he is still intubated primarily for altered mental status. However, his respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) is favorable, allowing him to tolerate spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) for up to three hours. The plan is to continue with repeated SBT and eventually work towards extubation over the next few days. If there is no progress, a tracheotomy tube may be considered.

The patient's blood pressure is marginal, suggesting possible hypotension. It is recommended to maintain a neutral fluid balance and gradually wean off vasopressors while monitoring the mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

The patient has an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, but the etiology is unclear. It could potentially be due to the stress response given the elevated AM cortisol levels.

The patient's mental status has significantly improved on a daily basis. Sedation medications are being held, and his mental status is being closely monitored.

The patient has hepatic failure attributed to VOD confirmed by biopsy results. He received 25 days of defibrotide, which was discontinued due to systemic adverse events such as SAH. His hepatic function is slowly resolving, as indicated by improving INR and albumin levels, although his bilirubin levels are still elevated. Ursodiol is being administered through the oral gastric tube (OGT).

The patient is tolerating continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVHD) and may require long-term hemodialysis (HD).

There is a corneal lesion in the right eye, which is enlarging. It is uncertain whether this is caused by dry eyes, fungal, or herpes infection. An ophthalmologist will evaluate the patient, and eye drop therapy will be continued as per the recommendations of the ophthalmologist. Cultures from the eye will also be obtained.

The patient's history of follicular lymphoma and recent BEAM auto SCT are being managed by the bone marrow transplant unit and social work team. Prophylactic antibiotics (Bactrim) and antiviral medication (acyclovir) are being administered.

In terms of ICU care, the patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with lipids and has multiple lines inserted, including an arterial line. Prophylaxis measures include stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and ventilation-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis through head-of-bed elevation, mouth care, daily wake-up, and RSBI monitoring.

Based on the information provided in the progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition:

1. The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and subsequently developed fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient's course was further complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

2. The patient's respiratory status has improved significantly, but there are concerns about his mental status changes, which may require ongoing airway protection.

3. The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and possibly sepsis. The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and there is ongoing debate regarding antifungal treatment.

4. The patient has leukocytosis with an unclear etiology, as cultures have been negative, and no abscess was found on CT.

5. The patient's hepatic failure is resolving, although bilirubin levels remain elevated. Ursodiol has been initiated to manage this condition.

6. The patient has oliguric acute renal failure (ARF) with ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) as the likely cause. CVVHD has been

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. The patient remains critically ill but has made some progress. He continues to be intubated primarily for altered mental status. His respiratory status is favorable, allowing for repeated spontaneous breathing trials (SBT), and there is a hope to work towards extubation over the next several days. If no progress is made, a tracheotomy tube may be considered.

The patient also has hypotension, possibly related to intravascular volume status. Fluid balance should be maintained, and vasopressor weaning is planned while monitoring mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

A non-sustained ventricular tachycardia occurred, but the cause is unclear. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated but stable, and the etiology is unknown. His mental status has improved, and sedation medications are being held.

The patient has hepatic failure attributed to VOD, which is resolving with ongoing treatment. Renal failure is present, and the patient is tolerating continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD). Long-term hemodialysis may be required. A corneal lesion in the right eye is being evaluated.

The patient's cancer history includes refractory follicular lymphoma and recent BEAM Auto SCT. B

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from another hospital with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. He remains critically ill but has shown overall progress. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated primarily for altered mental status. The RSBI is favorable, and he has tolerated spontaneous breathing trials for 3 hours with an IPS of 5 and PEEP of 5. The plan is to continue working towards extubation over the next several days. If there is no progress, a tracheotomy tube may be considered.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to altered mental status. The goal is to continue with repeated spontaneous breathing trials and eventually work towards extubation.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to have marginal intravascular volume status. It is recommended to maintain a net even fluid balance and wean off vasopressor support. Monitor mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.
3. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient experienced a non-sustained ventricular tachycardia, but the precipitant is unclear. It may be related to toxic metabolic insult, intrinsic heart disease, or electrolyte imbalances. Monitor heart rate (HR).
4. Elevated White Blood Cell

   56 yo M with refractory follicular lymphoma, s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease s/p defibrotide treatment that was stopped due to SAH, the
   course was further complicated by persistent hypotension,
   culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and
   respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.  Since stopping
   defibrotide, the patient has continued to improve vis-a-vis mental
   status and respiratory stability.
   # Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for airway
   protection due to mental status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy.
   By [**5-10**], the patient's respiratory status is much improved with RSBI 55
   this AM but unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for
   adequate airway protection and given his generalized debillitation, it
   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own
   - repeat SBTs daily
   - check NIF daily
   - check RSBI daily
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days
   ago given cdiff negative lab results and then restarted on [**4-28**] and
   later d/c'd on [**5-5**]. Cortisol normal vs elevated.
   - Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of
   MAP>65, SBP>85
   - Wean pressors as tolerated
   - Continue CRRT but will monitor BP closely
   # Leukocytosis: WBC elevated but stable. Unclear etiology, given pt is
   s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc IV+PO, with negative
   cultures to date. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis.  [**Month (only) 8**] be due to stress
   response given elevated AM cortisol.
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u BMT recs
   # Goals of care.  BMT social work following.  DNR with no major
   escalations.
   - Goals have changed little while clinical status stabilized --> give
   patient chance to declare wishes
   # Altered Mental Status: Significantly improved in past 72 hours.  Now
   off sedation; patient is responding appropriately to questions but
   still has minimal movement of extremities.  Thought [**3-4**] toxic/metabolic
   encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia.  EEG r/o

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) and developed fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). He also had severe sepsis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), respiratory failure requiring ventilator support, and leukocytosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory status: Improved with a respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) of 62. However, he still requires ventilator support due to mental status changes and potential inadequate airway protection.
- Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. The etiology is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. - Leukocytosis: Elevated white blood cell count, but stable. The etiology is unclear, given that the patient has had recent line changes without abscess on CT, is on vancomycin intravenously and orally, with negative cultures to date. No polymorphonuclear leukocytes were seen on paracentesis.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a heart rate of 133 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 89-112 mmHg, respiratory rate of 37 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is receiving norepinephrine at 0.03 mcg/kg/min, calcium gluconate at 1.2 grams/hour, and potassium chloride at 3 mEq/hour as part of CRRT. Other medications include pantoprazole, midazolam, and fentanyl. Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted below.
