   Assessment and Plan
   56 yom refractory follicular lymphoma, s/p BEAM Auto SCT, transferred
   from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive disease
   (VOD).   Overall continued progress, although remains critically ill.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- remains intubated primarily for altered mental
   status.  RSBI favorable, and able to tolerate SBT x 3 hrs (IPS=
   5/PEEP=5).  Hope to continue to work with repeated SBT, and eventually
   hope to work towards extubation trial over next several days.  If no
   progress, then tracheotomy tube.
   HYPOTENSION -- appears to be marginal for intravascular volume status.
   Would favor maintaining net even fluid balance, hope to wean
   vasopressor.  Monitor MAP > 60 mmHg.
   VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA -- non-sustained.  Unclear obvious precipitant,
   although may be related to toxic metabolic insult, intrinsic heart
   disease, electolyte.  Monitor HR.
   ELEVATED WBC -- continues to increase over days. Unclear etiology, but
   concern for evolving infection -- concerns include line-related
   infection, intraabdominal infection such as SBP, hepatobiliary
   infection (including fungal infection), C. diff colitis.  Recheck blood
   cultures, stool culture, stoo for C. diff.  Consider re-imaging study,
   and site directed paracentesis if fluid collection identified.
   Consider empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff Rx.
   ALTERED MENTAL STATUS -- much improved on daily basis.  Hold sedation
   medications.  Monitor mental status.
   MOTOR WEAKNESS -- diffuse motor weakness.  Fasculations noted in arms
   today.  Neurology to assess, ?EMG and NCS.

He was transferred from another hospital with fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient remains critically ill but has shown overall progress. He is currently intubated for respiratory failure and altered mental status. His respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%. His blood gases show a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 353, respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 62, plateau pressure of 11 cmH2O, and peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 14 cmH2O.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated primarily for altered mental status. The RSBI is favorable, allowing for periods of spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) with intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPS). The goal is to continue working towards extubation over the next few days. If there is no progress, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

   # Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for airway
   protection due to mental status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy.

   this AM but unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for
   adequate airway protection and given his generalized debillitation, it
   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own
   - repeat SBTs daily
   - check NIF daily
   - check RSBI daily
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days

   s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc IV+PO, with negative
   cultures to date. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis.  [**Month (only) 8**] be due to stress

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation and is now in the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide but was discontinued because of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, hepatic failure, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. The patient's mental status has improved significantly over the past 72 hours, but he still exhibits minimal movement of extremities. His respiratory status has also improved, with a reduced need for ventilatory support.

The patient's medical team is considering the potential complications that may arise based on his current conditions. These potential complications include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. The team plans to continue daily repeat spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) to assess the patient's ability to breathe on his own. The team will also monitor the patient's negative inspiratory force (NIF) and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) daily.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous bone marrow transplant (auto SCT) and is currently in the ICU. The patient has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, hypotension, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, hepatic failure with veno-occlusive disease (VOD), anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, but there are concerns about his mental status and airway protection. He remains intubated due to mental status changes and encephalopathy. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures are negative. The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for a long time.

Leukocytosis is present but stable, with unclear etiology. The patient is being followed for line changes, cultures, and bone marrow recommendations. Goals of care include BMT social work follow-up, DNR with no major escalations, and giving the patient a chance to declare his wishes.

The patient's hepatic failure is resolving, but elevated bilirubin persists. Trend liver function tests (LFTs) daily and start ursodiol via oral gastrointestinal tube (OGT). O

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) but developed fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide. The course was further complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient's mental status and respiratory stability have improved. The patient remains intubated for airway protection and generalized debilitation, with ongoing concerns about hypotension, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, ileus, and follicular lymphoma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved, but there is still uncertainty about his ability to breathe on his own due to mental status changes and generalized debilitation. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) will be performed to assess readiness for extubation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirements have decreased, but hypotension persists due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sepsis is also a concern, despite negative cultures. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered, and the

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient's current condition is described as critically ill with several medical complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to marked motor weakness. The Respiratory System Compliance Index (RSBI) is favorable, allowing for intermittent spontaneous breathing trials (SBT). The goal is to continue working towards extubation over the next few days, but if there is no progress, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

2. Hypotension: The patient appears to have marginal intravascular volume status. Fluid balance should be maintained, and the vasopressor can be weaned while monitoring mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

3. Elevated White Blood Cell (WBC) Count: The WBC count continues to increase, which may indicate an evolving infection. Possible sources include line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), or Clostridium difficile colitis. Blood cultures, stool culture, and stool testing for C. difficile should be repeated. Site-directed paracentesis may be considered if fluid collection is identified

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated primarily for marked motor weakness. RSBI is favorable, and he is able to tolerate spontaneous breathing trials intermittently. The goal is to continue with repeated SBT and eventually work towards extubation over the next several days. If there is no progress, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

2. Hypotension: The patient appears to be marginal for intravascular volume status. It is recommended to maintain a neutral fluid balance and wean off vasopressors. Monitor mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg.

3. Elevated White Blood Cell Count: The WBC count continues to increase over days, and the etiology is unclear. There is concern for evolving infection, including line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), and Clostridium difficile colitis. Recheck blood cultures, stool culture, and stool for C. diff. Consider re-imaging study and site-directed paracentesis if fluid collection is identified. The patient is now on empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff Rx.

   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own
   - repeat SBTs daily
   - check NIF daily
   - check RSBI daily
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days
   ago given cdiff negative lab results and then restarted on [**4-28**] and
   later d/c'd on [**5-5**]. Cortisol normal vs elevated.
   - Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of
   MAP>65, SBP>85
   - Wean pressors as tolerated
   - Continue CRRT but will monitor BP closely
   # Leukocytosis: WBC elevated but stable. Unclear etiology, given pt is
   s/p line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc IV+PO, with negative
   cultures to date. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis.  [**Month (only) 8**] be due to stress
   response given elevated AM cortisol.
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u BMT recs
   # Goals of care.  BMT social work following.  DNR with no major
   escalations.
   - Goals have changed little while clinical status stabilized --> give
   patient chance to declare wishes
   # Altered Mental Status: Significantly improved in past 72 hours.  Now
   off sedation; patient is responding appropriately to questions but
   still has minimal movement of extremities.  Thought [**3-4**] toxic/metabolic
   encephalopathy from liver failure and/or uremia.  EEG r/o
   nonconvulsive status epilepticus; consistent with encephalopathy.
   - continue lactulose [**Hospital1 **]
   - hold sedation medications
   # Hepatic Failure: VOD [**3-4**] SCT, confirmed by biopsy results. Patient
   received 25 days of defibrotide that was d/c'd [**3-4**] SAH. Hepatic failure
   resolving (INR, Albumin), but elevated TBili persists (though improved
   from peak).
   - trend LFTs daily
   - Ursodiol via OGT
   # Oliguric ARF: Pt started on CVVHD [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function.  Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts).  Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome.  Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP.  Renal is following.
   - Continue CVVHD per renal recs, with goal of net even / 24 hrs with
   close monitoring of blood pressure
   - Trend pH, calcium, lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   - Dose meds for CVVHD
   - f/u renal recs
   # Anasarca
 Almost completely resolved s/p removal of fluid via CRRT.
   - run CRRT even at this time as trying to take off additional fluid
   results in BP drop and increased pressor requirement
   - left upper ext U/S for increased swelling
 negative for DVT
   # corneal lesion: right eye has a corneal lesion, enlarging.  Question
   if this due to dry eyes/fungal/herpes infection
   - opthal will eval,f/u recs
 continue eye drops ([**Last Name (LF) 4075**], [**First Name3 (LF) **])
   - eye cultures unremarkable
   # ileus
 Now resolved, with significant BMs on lactulose.
   - continue lactulose [**Hospital1 **]

   Work are following.
   - Continue Bactrim ppx.  Acyclovir ppx being held at this time.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation. He was transferred to the ICU with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide but stopped due to subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient's mental status has improved in the past 72 hours, and he is now off sedation, responding appropriately to questions, but still has minimal movement of extremities. The patient's respiratory status has also improved, but it is unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for adequate airway protection.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) should be repeated to assess the patient's ability to breathe on his own. The patient's respiratory status should continue to be monitored closely.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Sedation may also contribute to the hypotension. Pressors may be required to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease. The patient has been treated with defibrotide, which was stopped due to subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, but there are concerns about his mental status and airway protection. The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far.

The patient has leukocytosis with an unclear etiology, negative cultures, and positive sputum gram stain. The differential diagnosis includes infection (such as Clostridium difficile) versus leukemoid reaction. Infection control measures are being followed, including checking for cdiff, resiting lines, and following recommendations from BMT and ID consultants.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and is currently in the ICU with multiple complications. 

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure and remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. His respiratory status has improved, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) and respiratory system assessment with noninvasive ventilation (NIV) monitoring are recommended. 

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and sedation. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far. Pressors and IV fluid boluses should be given as needed to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 65 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) greater than 85 mmHg.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis with an unclear etiology. Infection or leukemoid reaction should be considered, and further follow-up cultures and consultations with BMT and infectious disease (ID) teams are recommended.

4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has significantly improved after stopping sedation. An electroenceph

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and was transferred from a bone marrow transplant unit. The patient is currently in the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure secondary to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient remains critically ill, although there has been gradual improvement in overall condition.

The patient continues to have respiratory failure and remains intubated primarily for marked motor weakness. The patient's Respiratory Support Index (RSI) is favorable, allowing for intermittent spontaneous breathing trials (SBT). The goal is to continue working towards extubation over the next few days. If there is no progress, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

The patient also has hypotension, which is believed to be related to intravascular volume status. Maintaining a balanced fluid intake and output is recommended, with the goal of weaning off vasopressors and maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

There is an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, which has slightly decreased but remains elevated. This could indicate an evolving infection, possibly line-related, intraabdominal, hepatobiliary, or C. difficile colitis. Blood cultures, stool culture, and testing for C. difficile should be repeated. Empirical antimicrobials, including treatment for C.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and was transferred to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient remains critically ill and is currently intubated for respiratory failure, primarily due to marked motor weakness. The patient's respiratory status is improving, as indicated by a favorable respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) and the ability to tolerate spontaneous breathing trials intermittently.

The patient's blood pressure is marginal, indicating potential hypotension, and there is concern for an evolving infection, possibly line-related or intra-abdominal. The elevated white blood cell count suggests an infection, and cultures have been ordered to identify the causative agent. The patient is already on empirical antibiotics, including treatment for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis.

The patient's mental status has improved daily, and sedation medications are being held. Neurological evaluation is planned to assess motor weakness, including electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies (NCS).

The patient has hepatic failure attributed to VOD post-SCT, which is resolving, although the patient previously experienced a serious adverse event of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) while receiving defibrotide. Ursodiol is being administered via orogastric tube (OGT).

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and was transferred from another hospital due to fulminant hepatic failure secondary to VOD. He remains critically ill and continues to show only gradual progress.

The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated for respiratory failure, primarily due to marked motor weakness. His respiratory system is favorable, and he can tolerate spontaneous breathing trials intermittently. The goal is to continue working towards repeated spontaneous breathing trials and eventually plan for extubation over the next few days. If there is no progress, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

The patient's blood pressure is marginal, indicating potential hypotension. It is recommended to maintain a neutral fluid balance and gradually wean off vasopressors while monitoring the mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

The patient's white blood cell count remains markedly elevated, which could be due to an evolving infection such as line-related infection, intraabdominal infection (e.g., spontaneous bacterial peritonitis), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), or Clostridium difficile colitis. Blood cultures, stool culture, and stool testing for C. difficile have been ordered. Empirical antimicrobials, including C. difficile treatment, have been initiated.

The patient's mental status has improved daily, and sedation medications

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto transplant and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease. The patient's clinical course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. 

The patient's vital signs show a heart rate of 116 bpm, blood pressure of 75/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's CVP is 4 mmHg, and the total fluid input is 9,608 mL with a total fluid output of 8,551 mL, resulting in a fluid balance of 1,057 mL. The patient is receiving calcium gluconate (CRRT), KCl (CRRT), and norepinephrine infusions. 

Laboratory results indicate WBC count of 41.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.2 g/dL, platelet count of 123 K/uL, creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL, total bilirubin of 35.6%, and glucose of 136 mg/dL. Other lab results show elevated levels of ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase, total protein, albumin, lactate, and LDH, while being within normal range for calcium, magnesium, phosphate, and potassium.

The patient's assessment includes ongoing respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, oliguric acute renal failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. 

The patient's plan includes weaning off sedation, tracheostomy consideration, repeat spontaneous breathing trials daily, checking NIF and RSBI daily, and maintaining IV fluid and pressor support as needed. The patient's antibiotic regimen has been adjusted multiple times, and further evaluation of infection and leukocytosis is ongoing. The patient's hepatic failure is resolving, and the dose of ursodiol will be given via oral gastric tube. The patient's oliguric acute renal failure will continue with CVVHD, and close monitoring of blood pressure is essential. The patient's anasarca has almost completely resolved, and CRRT will continue. The corneal lesion will be evaluated by ophthalmology, and lactulose will be continued for constipation.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant unit due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by VOD. The patient remains critically ill and is currently on mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure. He has diffuse profound motor weakness and is unable to tolerate an extubation trial. A tracheostomy tube placement is planned. The patient's blood pressure is low, indicating potential hypotension, which may be related to CVVH. His white blood cell count is markedly elevated, and there are concerns for evolving infection. The patient is on empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff treatment. His mental status has improved, and sedation medications are being held. The patient's hepatic failure is attributed to VOD and has partially resolved. He received 25 days of defibrotide but was discontinued due to SAH. The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and he requires long-term hemodialysis. A corneal lesion in the right eye is enlarging, and further evaluation is needed. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant (SCT) and was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit due to fulminant hepatic failure attributed to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). The patient remains critically ill and has been intubated for marked motor weakness. His respiratory failure is expected to continue as he is unable to tolerate extubation due to profound motor weakness, and a tracheostomy tube placement is planned. The patient's hypotension is thought to be related to continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and efforts are being made to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg while weaning vasopressors.

The patient's white blood cell count is markedly elevated, and there is concern for evolving infection, including line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), and Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis. Blood cultures, stool culture, stool for C. diff, and ascites culture have been ordered, and empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff treatment, have been initiated.

The patient's mental status has improved but remains altered. Sedation medications have been held, and mental status is being closely monitored. The patient also has diffuse motor weakness, with fasciculations noted in the

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU for fulminant hepatic failure, occlusive disease, and other complications. He has been intubated and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's condition has stabilized, but he still requires pressor support for hypotension and ongoing renal replacement therapy (CRRT). His mental status has improved, and he is responding appropriately to questions. However, he remains minimally active. The patient's liver function is improving, but he still has elevated bilirubin levels. He is also experiencing oliguric acute renal failure, likely secondary to ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and hepatorenal syndrome. There are no signs of infection or sepsis, and his leukocytosis may be due to a leukemoid reaction or infection. The patient has corneal lesions in his right eye, which require further evaluation. His anasarca has resolved, and he is no longer experiencing ileus.

Potential medical complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a possibility of extubation in the future if his respiratory status improves.
2. Hypotension: The patient requires pressor support to maintain blood pressure within the desired range. The underlying causes of hypotension include intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume,

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure. The patient has had multiple complications, including occlusive disease treated with defibrotide (stopped due to SAH), persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient's mental status and respiratory stability have improved since stopping defibrotide. The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes, sedation, and encephalopathy.

The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, hypotension, leukocytosis, hepatic failure, oliguric ARF, anasarca, corneal lesion, ileus, and follicular lymphoma. The patient is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungal medications. The patient's goals of care are to stabilize his condition and provide comfort, with a DNR status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still intubated and requires airway protection due to mental status changes, sedation, and encephalopathy. There is uncertainty regarding the patient's ability to breathe on his own, and the need for a tracheostomy may be considered.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to intravascular

3. Elevated white blood cell count (WBC): The patient's WBC count remains markedly elevated, which could indicate an evolving infection. Further investigations are needed to determine the source of infection, such as line-related infection, intraabdominal infection, hepatobiliary infection, or C. difficile colitis. Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. The patient remains critically ill and has shown only gradual progress. The main medical complications include respiratory failure, hypotension, elevated white blood cell count, altered mental status, motor weakness, hepatic failure, ventricular tachycardia, renal failure, and a corneal lesion.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still intubated due to marked motor weakness. There is a plan to proceed with tracheostomy tube placement as the patient is unlikely to tolerate extubation.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to have marginal intravascular volume status and is being treated with vasopressors. The goal is to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg and wean off the vasopressors.
3. Elevated White Blood Cell Count: The patient's WBC count is markedly elevated, which may indicate an evolving infection. Potential sources of infection include line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), or Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis.    MICU Attending Addendum:
   I examined Mr [**Known lastname 11910**] today and was present for the key portion of the
   services provided.  I have reviewed Dr [**First Name (STitle) 9683**]
s note above and agree
   with his findings and plan of care.  Mr [**Known lastname 11910**] has had a very complex
   and prolonged MICU stay following his BMTx for lymphoma.  He suffers
   from portal hypertension from hepatic venoocclusive disease from GVHD,
   as well as renal failure and resp failure.  The latter currently is
   largely due to his profound muscle weakness and fairly tense ascites,
   as his CXR is quite clear.  Today he
s quite alert and comfortable on
   vent with his new trache, and on only minimal vent support on PSV of
   [**11-4**] and 40% Fi02.  Of some concern is his persistent leukocytosis,
   still over 30k despite its improving. We have just started Ceftaz for
   PSA in bronchial secretions, but it remains to be seen if this will
   result in his becoming afebrile and with normal WBC. He
s been
   hypotensive since trache,  and I would favor a fluid bolus, but if
   albumin is low, would prefer colloid.  We appreciate involvement of
   consultants, and will follow renal recs as far as queuing him up for
   more permanent renal dialysis and tunneled line for such.  45 min spent
   in the care of this critically ill patient.
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 712**], MD

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation (SCT) and is now in the ICU with multiple complications. The patient has been diagnosed with fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease of the liver, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. The patient also has leukocytosis with an unclear etiology, oliguric acute renal failure likely secondary to ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and an altered mental status that has improved significantly.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hepatic Failure: The patient's hepatic failure is due to veno-occlusive disease of the liver, which occurred as a complication of the stem cell transplantation. This condition can lead to liver dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications such as coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and hepatorenal syndrome.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure, which is characterized by a decrease in kidney function and an inability to produce urine. This condition requires immediate medical intervention to manage fluid and electrolyte imbalances and prevent further complications.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant (BMT) unit with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The patient's clinical course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient has shown improvement in mental status and respiratory stability.

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes, sedation, and encephalopathy. His respiratory status has improved significantly, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. The plan is to perform tracheostomy today, repeat spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) daily, check negative inspiratory force (NIF) daily, and continue monitoring respiratory system compliance and resistance (RSBI) daily.

2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirement has reduced overnight. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchnic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone BEAM Auto SCT (bone marrow transplant) and is currently in the ICU due to several complications. The patient's conditions include respiratory failure requiring ventilator support, hypotension with ongoing pressor requirements, acute renal failure requiring continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), hepatic failure secondary to VOD (veno-occlusive disease) after SCT, anasarca (generalized edema), and a corneal lesion in the right eye.

The patient underwent a percutaneous tracheostomy and has been on multiple antibiotics, including tobramycin, meropenem, Bactrim, and vancomycin, due to concerns of infection. However, cultures have remained negative except for a positive sputum gram stain.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 121 bpm, hypotension with blood pressure readings ranging from 97/58 mmHg to 66/42 mmHg, and an increased respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation remains at 100% on the ventilator. 

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly elevated bilirubin levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's creatinine level is within normal range, but renal function is impaired as indicated by the requirement for CRRT.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto transplant and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient's mental status and respiratory stability have improved.

Current Issues:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. His respiratory status has improved, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) will be repeated, and the need for continued ventilatory support will be assessed.
2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirement has reduced overnight. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. Sepsis is also a concern, although cultures remain negative. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered. Vancomycin was discontinued due to Clostridium difficile (C. diff) negative lab results but was restarted and later discontinued again. Cortisol levels are normal or elevated. The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT (bone marrow transplant) and was transferred from BMT (bone marrow transplant) unit with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide but stopped due to SAH (subarachnoid hemorrhage). The patient also has persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, hypotension, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, hepatic failure, altered mental status, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. The patient is s/p (status post) BEAM auto SCT and is currently on day 24 of the procedure.

The patient has multiple medical complications that can arise, including but not limited to:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes and sedation. Daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs) are planned to assess readiness for extubation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. Pressor requirements have reduced overnight, but careful monitoring

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto transplant and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure. The patient's course was complicated by occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide but had to be stopped due to SAH. The patient also experienced persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, hypotension, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. The patient's respiratory status has improved, but it is unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for adequate airway protection.

The patient's hypotension is being treated with pressors and IV fluid boluses as needed to maintain MAP > 65 and SBP > 85. The etiology of the hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date.

The patient's oliguric ARF is due to ischemic ATN with muddy brown

   On this day I examined Mr [**Known lastname 11910**], spoke with his wife, and was present
   for the key portion of the services provided.  I have reviewed Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) **]
s note above and agree with his findings and plan of care.
   Despite his art line showing hypotension enough to require Levophed, he
   seems warm and well perfused and is mentating clearly. We will measure
   cuff BP to be sure art line is not artifactual.  He had SOB on PSV
   yesterday and is now back on A/C and comfortable. Will check CXR to be
   sure not new infiltrates. If not, I would try to get him back on PSV,
   even starting at high pressure support levels of 15-20.
   Unfortunately he was anuric off of CVVH and became an additional 4L
   positive.  He will get tunneled dialysis cathether early next week and
   start HD.  He seems mostly very deconditoned to me and I would start an
   aggressive physical therapy program.  Fortunately his WBC has fallen
   nicely over 24 hr and hopefully fever trend will follow suit.
   40min spent in the care of this critically ill patient.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who was transferred from another hospital with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient's condition has improved, including mental status changes and respiratory stability. 

The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. His respiratory status has improved significantly, but it is unclear if he is strong enough to breathe on his own. The patient's hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far. 

The patient's oliguric acute renal failure is believed to be ischemic ATN secondary to hypotension, likely hepatorenal syndrome. The etiology of leukocytosis is unclear, with no abscess per CT, negative cultures, and no evidence of line infection. 

The patient's altered mental status has improved significantly, now off sedation and responding appropriately to questions, but still with minimal movement of extremities. An EEG ruled out nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone BEAM auto stem cell transplantation (SCT) and is now in the ICU. The patient's clinical course has been complicated by fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD) post-SCT, which required treatment with defibrotide but was stopped due to the development of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient also experienced persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, hypotension, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, ileus, and follicular lymphoma. The patient's treatment plan includes weaning off sedation and pressors, performing daily spontaneous breathing trials (SBTs), checking NIF (not specified), following up with BMT (bone marrow transplant) social work, SW (social work) follow-up, rest at night, monitoring albumin levels, restarting CVVHD if necessary, checking pH, calcium, electrolytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os, dosing medications for CVVHD, following up with renal recommendations, checking cultures, considering antif

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 98-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hepatic failure, and hypotension. The patient has a history of malignancy, liver function abnormalities, and a recent subarachnoid hemorrhage. The patient's condition has been complicated by an infection, with blood cultures obtained twice. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, receiving TPN with lipids, and has a central venous catheter in place. The patient's blood pressure remains low, and he is receiving norepinephrine infusion. The patient's family has expressed a desire for neuro involvement to rule out neuropathy from autoimmune origin, and an albumin level is being checked.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient's blood cultures indicate an ongoing infection, which needs to be promptly identified and treated to prevent further complications.
2. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension despite norepinephrine infusion may indicate inadequate organ perfusion and can lead to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.
3. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure could progress to ARDS, a life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure can worsen if renal perfusion is compromised due to persistent hypotension or ongoing sepsis.
5. Hepatic Encephalopathy

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto transplant and was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit. The patient's medical history includes fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease, persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes and sedation. His respiratory status has improved, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. Tracheostomy was performed on [**5-16**].

2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirement has reduced overnight. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures are negative. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered.

3. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient started on CVVHD for worsening metabolic acidosis and worsening renal function. The initial insult was hypotension, most likely leading to hepatorenal syndrome. The patient remains severely oliguric with no indication of improved

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM Auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The patient's course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient has shown improvement in mental status and respiratory stability.

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided are:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes and encephalopathy. There is uncertainty regarding his ability to breathe on his own.

2. Hypotension: The etiology is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date.

3. Oliguric ARF: The patient has ischemic ATN (urine sediment with muddy brown casts) and initial insult likely hepatorenal syndrome. The patient remains severely oliguric with no indication of improved renal function.

4. Leukocytosis: The etiology is unclear, with negative cultures except for a positive sputum gram stain

The course was further complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient has improved mentally and respiratorily. 

The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. His respiratory status has improved, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. He also has a tracheostomy in place. A sputum culture grew MDR Pseudomonas, so he is being treated with CTZ D4/7 and repeated spontaneous breathing tests (SBTs) are being done.

The patient's hypotension has reduced pressor requirements overnight, but the etiology is still being investigated. It is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is concern for sepsis, although cultures are negative, and he has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for a long time. Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who has undergone BEAM Auto stem cell transplantation (SCT). The patient was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant (BMT) unit to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by occlusive disease, which was treated with defibrotide but had to be stopped due to subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient's condition was further complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate (HR) of 114 beats per minute, blood pressure (BP) ranging from 122/74 to 96/60 mmHg, respiratory rate (RR) of 29 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 100%, and temperature (T) ranging from 37.3 to 37.2 degrees Celsius. The patient's physical examination reveals generalized edema and an enlarging corneal lesion in the right eye.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count (WBC) of 36.3 thousand/mm3, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count (Plt) of 103 thousand/mm3, hyponatremia with a sodium level (Na+) of 22 mEq/L, hyperkalemia with a potassium level (K+) of 5.3 mEq/L, elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT), hypocalcemia with a calcium level (Ca++) of 8.3 mg/dL, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 243 IU/L. Renal function tests indicate acute renal failure with a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 36 mg/dL and a creatinine level (Cr) of 2.4 mg/dL.

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, hypotension, oliguric acute renal failure, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic failure, anasarca, corneal lesion, ileus, and follicular lymphoma. The patient has a do-not-resuscitate (DNR) code status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to stem cell transplantation and prolonged ICU stay increases the risk of infection. The presence of leukocytosis and positive sputum culture for Pseudomonas aeruginosa suggests a possible respiratory tract infection.
2. Bleeding: The patient's coagulation profile (PT/INR/PTT) indicates a prolonged clotting time, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease if not properly managed.
4. Hepatic failure: Although the patient's hepatic function is improving, there is still a risk of further liver damage and complications such as hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's dependence on mechanical ventilation suggests a high risk of respiratory failure and associated complications.
6. Corneal lesion: The enlarging corneal lesion in the right eye requires further evaluation and treatment to prevent further complications.
7. Anasarca: The patient's generalized edema may indicate fluid overload and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause and prevent complications related to fluid management.
8. Follicular lymphoma: The patient's underlying malignancy may continue to progress and cause complications.

It is important to monitor the patient closely and address

   56 yo M with refractory follicular lymphoma, s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease s/p defibrotide treatment that was stopped due to SAH, the
   course was further complicated by persistent hypotension,
   culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and
   respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.  Since stopping
   defibrotide, the patient has improved vis-a-vis mental status and
   respiratory stability.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for airway
   protection due to mental status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy.
   By [**5-10**], the patient's respiratory status is much improved with RSBI 55
   this AM but unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for
   adequate airway protection and given his generalized debilitation, it
   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. S/P
   trach on [**5-16**].  MDR Pseudomonas grew out on latest sputum cx.
   - continue CTZ D3/7
   - repeat SBTs daily
   - check NIF daily
   - Pt following
   - SW following
   - rest at night
   - f/u cxr
   .
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days
   ago given cdiff negative lab results and then restarted on [**4-28**] and
   later d/c'd on [**5-5**]. Cortisol normal vs elevated.
   - Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet goals of
   MAP>65, SBP>85
   - Wean pressors as tolerated
   - check albumin level, may consider giving albumin IV x 1 if low
   - held CVVH for one day, but likely will need to restart per renal
   - need to get HD tunnelled line prior to discharge
   .
   # Oliguric ARF: Pt started on CVVHD [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function.  Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts).  Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome.  Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP.  Renal is following.
   - Continue CVVHD per renal recs, with goal of net even / 24 hrs with
   close monitoring of blood pressure
   - Trend pH, calcium, lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   - Dose meds for CVVHD
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   # Leukocytosis:  Unclear etiology, given pt is s/p line changes with no
   abscess per CT, on Vanc PO, with negative cultures save for + sputum
   gram stain. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis and no BP on [**5-13**] para.
   Infection (c diff?) vs leukemoid reaction

 pseudomonas (tobra/[**Last Name (un) **] resistent)
 on CTZ D3/7

   sample)
   - f/u BMT recs
 question if this is another malignancy

   # Altered Mental Status: Significantly improved.  Now off sedation;

 negative for DVT

 Now resolved, with significant BMs on lactulose.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto transplant. He was transferred from the bone marrow transplant unit to the ICU due to fulminant hepatic failure secondary to veno-occlusive disease (VOD), which was treated with defibrotide but stopped due to the development of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient also had persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD), and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes. His respiratory status has improved, but it is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on CPAP/PSV mode with FiO2 set at 40%. His RSBI is 87.
2. Hypotension: The patient's pressor requirements have reduced overnight, suggesting an improvement in his condition. The etiology of hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative so far. The patient has

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from the Bone Marrow Transplant (BMT) unit. The patient presented with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD and continues to be critically ill.

Key Findings and Assessment:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains mechanically ventilated primarily for marked motor weakness. Monitor RR.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to be marginally hypotensive, possibly related to CVVH. Maintain a net even fluid balance and consider weaning vasopressor. Monitor MAP > 60 mmHg.
3. Elevated White Blood Cell Count (WBC): The WBC count remains markedly elevated, possibly due to persistent infection. Concerns include line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), Clostridium difficile colitis. Recheck blood cultures, stool culture, and stool for C. diff. Await ascites culture. Currently on empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff Rx. Plan to resite lines, including arterial line, dialysis catheter, and central line (may require Interventional Radiology guidance).
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved daily. Hold sedation medications

The patient remains critically ill and has several ongoing medical complications.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated primarily due to marked motor weakness. Continuous monitoring of respiratory rate is advised.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to have marginal intravascular volume status, possibly related to Continuous Venous Hemofiltration (CVVH). Maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg is recommended, and weaning of vasopressors should be considered.
3. Elevated White Blood Cell Count (WBC): The WBC count remains markedly elevated. There is concern for evolving infection, including line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), or Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis. Rechecking blood cultures, stool culture, stool for C. diff, and awaiting ascites culture is advised. The patient is already on empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff treatment.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved daily. Sedation medications should be held, and

The patient also had sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS), acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and sepsis. The patient's current condition is improving, with improved mental status and respiratory stability. However, he remains severely oliguric and on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). The patient has several ongoing medical complications that need to be addressed, including hypotension, leukocytosis, altered mental status, hepatic injury, anasarca, corneal lesion, and ileus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension despite reduced pressor requirements. This may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date. Pressors and IV fluid boluses will be used as needed to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) above 85 mmHg.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto transplant and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The patient's course has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. The patient's mental status has improved, but his respiratory stability is still uncertain. He has an active infection with MDR Pseudomonas. The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by intravascular volume depletion and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as sedation. The patient remains oliguric with no indication of improved renal function. The etiology of leukocytosis is unclear, and the patient has an active sputum infection with Pseudomonas. The patient's altered mental status has significantly improved, but he still has minimal movement of extremities. The patient's hepatic injury and history of failure due to VOD post-SCT have resolved, although elevated TBili persists. The patient's anasarca has almost completely resolved. The patient has a corneal lesion in the right eye, which is enlarging. The patient's ileus has resolved. The patient is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 24, and BMT and social work are following.

   56 yo M with refractory follicular lymphoma, s/p BEAM Auto [**Hospital 11923**]
   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease s/p defibrotide treatment that was stopped due to SAH, the
   course was further complicated by persistent hypotension,
   culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and
   respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.  Since stopping
   defibrotide, the patient has improved vis-a-vis mental status and
   respiratory stability.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for airway
   protection due to mental status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy.
   By [**5-10**], the patient's respiratory status is much improved with RSBI 55
   this AM but unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for
   adequate airway protection and given his generalized debilitation, it
   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. S/P
   trach on [**5-16**].  MDR Pseudomonas grew out on latest sputum cx.
   - continue CTZ D5/7
   - repeat SBTs, NIF daily
   - Pt & SW following
   - rest at night
   - f/u cxr
   .
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days
   ago given cdiff negative lab results and then restarted on [**4-28**] and
   later d/c'd on [**5-5**]. Cortisol normal vs elevated. RESOLVED on [**5-21**]
   - Off IV Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet
   goals of MAP>65, SBP>85
   - started midodrine, increase to 7.5 mg
   - held CVVH for one day, but likely will need to restart per renal
   - need to get HD tunnelled line prior to discharge
   .
   # Oliguric ARF: Pt started on CVVHD [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function.  Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts).  Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome.  Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP.  Renal is following.
   - Continue CVVHD per renal recs, with goal of net even / 24 hrs with
   close monitoring of blood pressure
   - Trend pH, calcium, lytes, BUN/Cr, Is/Os
   - Dose meds for CVVHD
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   # Leukocytosis:  Unclear etiology, given pt is s/p line changes with no
   abscess per CT, on Vanc PO, with negative cultures save for + sputum
   gram stain. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis and no BP on [**5-13**] para.
   Infection (c diff?) vs leukemoid reaction
   - f/u cultures
 pseudomonas (tobra/[**Last Name (un) **] resistent)
 on CTZ D3/7
   - cytology from tap negative for malignancy (though limited quantity
   sample)
   - f/u BMT recs
 question if this is another malignancy
   - f/u ID recs re: cdiff check, resite LIJ line --> no indication of
   line infection
   - D/C IV vanc
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Significantly improved.  Now off sedation;
   patient is responding appropriately to questions but still has minimal
   movement of extremities.  Thought [**3-4**] toxic/metabolic encephalopathy
   from liver failure and/or uremia.  EEG r/o
d nonconvulsive status
   epilepticus; consistent with encephalopathy.
   - continue lactulose [**Hospital1 **]
   - hold sedation medications
   .
   # Hepatic Injury, HIstory of Failure: VOD [**3-4**] SCT, confirmed by biopsy
   results. Patient received 25 days of defibrotide that was d/c'd [**3-4**]
   SAH. Hepatic failure resolving (INR, Albumin), but elevated TBili
   persists though improved from peak).
   - Ursodiol via NGT

   .

 Almost completely resolved s/p removal of fluid via CRRT.
   - run CRRT even at this time as trying to take off additional fluid
   results in BP drop and increased pressor requirement
   - left upper ext U/S for increased swelling
 negative for DVT
   .

   if this due to dry eyes/fungal/herpes infection
   - eye cultures unremarkable
   - finished course of eye drops
   .
   # ileus
 Now resolved, with significant BMs on lactulose.
   .
   # Follicular Lymphoma: Pt is s/p BEAM Auto SCT, day 24. BMT and Social

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM auto transplant and was transferred from the BMT unit due to fulminant hepatic failure caused by hepatic veno-occlusive disease. The patient's condition has been complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient's mental status and respiratory stability have improved. The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes and generalized debilitation. A multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas infection was identified in the sputum culture.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure. There is also a concern for sepsis, although cultures have been negative to date. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered, and the patient's pressor requirements have decreased overnight.
2. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's oliguric ARF is likely caused by ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hypotension. The initial insult may have been hepatorenal syndrome. The patient remains severely oliguric, and CVVHD is being continued to manage metabolic acidosis and

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent a BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from another hospital with fulminant hepatic failure due to veno-occlusive disease (VOD). 

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains mechanically ventilated primarily for marked motor weakness.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to be marginally hypotensive, possibly related to continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). It is recommended to maintain a neutral fluid balance and hope to wean off vasopressor. Monitor mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg.
3. Elevated White Blood Cell Count (WBC): The WBC count has slightly decreased but remains markedly elevated. Unclear etiology, but concern for persistent infection such as line-related infection, intraabdominal infection (e.g., spontaneous bacterial peritonitis), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), or Clostridium difficile colitis. Recheck blood cultures, stool culture, and stool for C. diff. Await ascites culture. The patient is already on empirical antimicrobials, including C. diff treatment. Plan to replace lines, including arterial line, dialysis catheter, and central line (may require interventional radiology

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. He remains critically ill, requiring mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure and vasopressor support for hypotension. His WBC count is still markedly elevated, causing concern for persistent infection. He has hepatic failure attributed to VOD, which is resolving with ongoing treatment. The patient also has renal failure and corneal lesions in his right eye. His current medications include TPN with lipids, Peptamen 1.5, calcium gluconate (CRRT), KCl (CRRT), fentanyl, pantoprazole, and Bactrim prophylaxis. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains mechanically ventilated due to marked motor weakness. Close monitoring of RR is necessary.
2. Hypotension: The patient appears to have marginal intravascular volume status and may be related to CVVH. Maintaining a balanced fluid intake and output is recommended. Vasopressor support should be continued to maintain MAP > 60 mmHg.
3. Elevated WBC: The patient's WBC count remains markedly elevated, which may indicate persistent infection. Further investigation is needed to determine the source of infection, including line-related infection, intraab

   transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure [**3-4**] [**Last Name (un) 3140**]-occlusive
   disease s/p defibrotide treatment that was stopped due to SAH, the
   course was further complicated by persistent hypotension,
   culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and
   respiratory failure requiring ventilator support.  Since stopping
   defibrotide, the patient has improved vis-a-vis mental status and
   respiratory stability.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Pt intubated [**4-10**], remains intubated for airway
   protection due to mental status changes [**3-4**] sedation + encephalopathy.
   By [**5-10**], the patient's respiratory status is much improved with RSBI 55
   this AM but unclear if his mental status has improved sufficiently for
   adequate airway protection and given his generalized debilitation, it
   is uncertain whether he is strong enough to breathe on his own. S/P
   trach on [**5-16**].  MDR Pseudomonas grew out on latest sputum cx.
   - continue CTZ D6/7

   - Pt & SW following

   - f/u cxr
   .
   # Hypotension: Reduced pressor requirement overnight. Etiology is
   currently thought to be combination of a) intravascular volume
   depletion [**3-4**] decreased effective circulating volume and splanchinic
   vasodilation from liver failure, and b) sedation.  Also concern for
   sepsis thoguh cultures negative to date and has been on broad spectrum
   antibiotics for a long time.  Switched from cefepime/flagyl  to
   meropenem [**4-25**]; meropenem was d/ced [**4-28**].  Given difference on opinion
   regarding antifungal treatement, maintained micafungin treatment -->
   later dc'd [**3-4**] hyperbilirubinemia.  PO vancomycin discontinued two days
   ago given cdiff negative lab results and then restarted on [**4-28**] and
   later d/c'd on [**5-5**]. Cortisol normal vs elevated. RESOLVED on [**5-21**]
   - Off IV Pressors, IV fluid boluses as needed for BP support to meet
   goals of MAP>65, SBP>85
   - started midodrine, increase to 7.5 mg
   - held CVVH for one day, but likely will need to restart per renal
   - need to get HD tunnelled line prior to discharge
   .
   # Oliguric ARF: Pt started on CVVHD [**2155-4-12**] for worsening metabolic
   acidosis and worsening renal function.  Etiology is ischemic ATN (urine
   sediment w/ muddy brown casts).  Initial insult = hypotension, most
   likely [**3-4**] hepatorenal syndrome.  Pt remains severely oliguric with no
   indication of improved renal function per UOP.  Renal is following.
   - Continue CVVHD per renal recs, with goal of net even / 24 hrs with

   abscess per CT, on Vanc PO, with negative cultures save for + sputum
   gram stain. No PMNs on [**4-25**] paracentesis and no BP on [**5-13**] para.
   Infection (c diff?) vs leukemoid reaction

 pseudomonas (tobra/[**Last Name (un) **] resistent)

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient. Some of the notable ones include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes and encephalopathy. The patient's respiratory status has improved, but it is unclear if their mental status has improved sufficiently for adequate airway protection.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is thought to be caused by a combination of intravascular volume depletion, decreased effective circulating volume, splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, and sedation. There is also concern for sepsis, although cultures are currently negative.

3. Oliguric Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient started CVVHD for worsening metabolic acidosis and worsening renal function. The etiology is ischemic ATN (urine sediment with muddy brown casts). The initial insult was likely hypotension, possibly hepatorenal syndrome. The patient remains severely oliguric with no indication of improved renal function.

4. Leukocytosis: The etiology of leukocytosis is unclear, given the patient's recent line changes with no abscess per CT, on Vanc PO, with negative cultures save for a positive sputum gram stain. There is a possibility of infection (such as Clostridium difficile) or a leukemoid reaction.

5. Altered Mental Status: The patient

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma who underwent BEAM auto SCT and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to occlusive disease treated with defibrotide. The course was complicated by persistent hypotension, culture-negative leukocytosis, acute renal failure requiring CVVHD, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. Since stopping defibrotide, the patient's mental status and respiratory stability have improved. 

The patient remains intubated for airway protection due to mental status changes, but his respiratory status has improved significantly. He has a tracheostomy tube in place. There is concern for MDR Pseudomonas infection, and the patient is on CTZ D6/7. 

The patient's hypotension is thought to be a combination of intravascular volume depletion and splanchinic vasodilation from liver failure, as well as possible sepsis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been administered, and the patient is being closely monitored for any signs of infection. 

The patient's oliguric ARF is believed to be ischemic ATN due to hypotension, most likely hepatorenal syndrome. CVVHD has been initiated, and the patient's renal function will be closely monitored. 

Leukocytosis is unclear in etiology, with negative cultures except for positive sputum gram stain. There is concern for infection, including Clostr

Summary: The patient is a 56-year-old male with refractory follicular lymphoma, who underwent BEAM Auto Stem Cell Transplantation (SCT) and was transferred from BMT with fulminant hepatic failure due to VOD. The patient remains critically ill, requiring mechanical ventilation and vasopressors for hypotension. The patient's respiratory failure is primarily due to marked motor weakness, and efforts are being made to wean off mechanical ventilation. There is a concern for persistent infection, including line-related infection, intraabdominal infection such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hepatobiliary infection (including fungal infection), and Clostridium difficile colitis. Blood cultures, stool culture, and stool for C. difficile have been ordered, and the patient is on empirical antimicrobials, including C. difficile treatment. The patient also has hepatic failure attributed to VOD secondary to SCT, which is resolving with 25 days of defibrotide. The patient's altered mental status has improved gradually, and sedation medications are being held. The patient's motor weakness is due to critical care illness, and there is gradual improvement. Renal failure is present, and the patient is tolerating continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD). A corneal lesion in the right eye is enlarging, and further evaluation is needed. The patient has a history of follicular lymphoma, s/p BEAM Auto SCT,
